https://t.co/q2gQ8JJP5o

3/ Benefits of OFTs include:

+Burned on a source chain and then issued to the destination chain, eliminating honeypots
+No canonical version of the token ‚Äî deployments on any chain have the same value
+No need for liquidity networks common in other bridging solutions

2/ As crypto went multichain, reliance on various bridging solutions to issue wrapped assets on a protocol's behalf created fungibility and utility issues.

OFTs allow any application to natively mint and burn a single, unified token standard across various chains. https://t.co/SP52Lbj7Tn

1/ Token standards (#Ethereum ERC-20, ERC-721) ensure tokens can be swapped & integrated into apps on a specific network.

6/ What are the challenges and implications of a protocol largely closed off to traditional risk vectors?

Find out in the full Pro report from @Saypien_.
https://t.co/WDtDgoBxaD

5/ Cont.

C. Traders lock loans into a private pool which is used to dial up and down leverage at the entry strike price.

D. Flash swaps can be used to execute transactions on-chain.

4/ How does @InfPools make this work?

A. LPs provide @Uniswap V3 tokens or raw liquidity into InifinityPools where it is made available to trade.

B. Infinity Pools combines LP assets into a new concentrated liquidity AMM pool called the Float Pool. https://t.co/EJ2CQgzeFS

3/ @InfPools uses LP positions as the loan source.

In doing so, the payback of the loan can be in either of the LP assets removing the traditional cash constraint.

This results in a few advantages:

+Unlimited Leverage
+Unlimited Assets
+No Oracles
+No Liquidations
+Scalability

2/ Normally, leveraged positions are created by borrowing cash ($USDC) from another party, which is expected to be paid back in the same asset borrowed.

When liquidated, leveraged assets must be sold for the exact amount of $USDC borrowed or bad debt occurs.

1/ @InfPools' leveraged swap protocol natively executes all facets of leveraged trades without outside, off-chain dependencies on liquidators, counterparties, or oracles like other leverage products, eliminating the inefficiencies of traditional DeFi primitives.üßµ https://t.co/o6xFOrkMYw

3/ Smart contracts on @WAX_io are written in C++, a popular language among Web2 devs.

+NET
+CPU
+RAM

NET and CPU cover network bandwidth costs of the network, and RAM for a user's data storage.

2/ Starting with @WAX_io's architecture, Wax employs a Delegated PoS (DPoS) mechanism where $WAXP token holders delegate their tokens to validators (‚ÄúWAX Guilds‚Äù), who produce and validate blocks.

https://t.co/ZhJUUyHaM0

7/ Transaction fees are paid to validators and stakers in $AXL, with conversion and payment handled through Axelar ‚Äòs Gas Services.

New $AXL tokens are minted to reward validators, which increases the total supply and makes $AXL an inflationary token. https://t.co/mqTIK5k2Cc

6/ Popular use cases for @axelarcore include:

+Cross-chain Governance
+Cross-chain NFTs
+Token Transfers

5/ So how does @axelarcore work?

A Proof-of-Stake blockchain built using @cosmos SDK.

Cross-chain Gateway Protocol (CGP) to relay and synchronize data across chains.

And Cross-Chain Transfer Protocol (CTP) to enable the transfer of assets and arbitrary messages across chains. https://t.co/4kQ80eFDMw

4/ Unlike most interoperability networks, @axelarcore allows gas fees to be paid once on the destination chain and with the destination token.

Axelar‚Äôs gas services conveniently handle all conversions required in the cross-chain transaction flow.

3/ A recent example of this is @circle's use of @axelarcore's GMP to support its Cross-chain Transfer Protocol (CCTP) for Composable $USDC.

This integration allows developers to seamlessly integrate $USDC into their dApps, which allows users to transact without wrapping assets.

2/ At its core, Axelar‚Äôs General Message Passing (GMP) advances the cross-chain communication of arbitrary data, enabling composable liquidity, cross-chain governance, and cross-chain transfer of assets that cannot be wrapped, such as NFTs.

1/ Branded as the "@stripe for Web3 applications", @axelarcore is filling the void for devs wanting to create interoperable solutions between blockchains with different consensus mechanisms via easy-to-use plug-and-play integration solutions.üßµ https://t.co/4uWQcihDDV

8/ For a complete look at the US Dollar's role as the global reserve currency, understanding USD liquidity conditions, and other factors to consider, check out the full Enterprise report from @0xArchytas.
https://t.co/qRYqoWM4hU

7/ With that understanding what does that mean for 2023's outlook?

With the debt ceiling reached earlier this month, the TGA is being spent down limiting new debt being issued.

If the Treasury does decide to sell bills, the RRP should drop and risk assets should rally. https://t.co/o3Mp0rJiMe

6/ The RRP offers similar rates as U.S. Treasury bills, except it carries no duration risk and only ‚Äúlocks‚Äù money overnight.

Money deposited into the RRP is effectively illiquid, as it isn‚Äôt lent out or deployed in any other way.

Increasing RRP is a net liquidity drain.

5/ The TGA being drawn down is positive for assets, as more dollars go out into the economy and less debt is issued.

When the TGA is increasing, that‚Äôs generally negative for assets, as increased debt issuance sucks dollars out of the system. https://t.co/yxP2jPiDGy

4/ While the Fed's balance sheet has had an important impact on risk asset prices, the Treasury General Account (TGA), or the Fed's ‚Äúbank account‚Äù, and the Reverse Repo Facility (RRP) play a role in the overall liquidity picture as well.

3/ QE and QT affect risk assets (i.e., crypto) through the ‚Äúportfolio rebalancing effect.‚Äù

During QE, this means money trickles down to risk assets.

QT is the opposite. To absorb the extra supply of these ‚Äúsafe‚Äù assets, investors sell assets at the riskiest end of the curve. https://t.co/vV439C9TqM

2/ This starts with the Federal Reserve Balance sheet, as cash flows affect dollar liquidity.

The Fed can create new cash reserves by buying assets, quantitative easing (QE).

Or reduce reserves by selling or allowing assets to mature, quantitative tightening (QT).
1/ Understanding the US Dollar's role as the global reserve currency can give us a better understanding of its effects on crypto asset prices.üßµ https://t.co/9pxNuU0AJl

8/ @POKTnetwork DAO is focused on building a fair and egalitarian DAO that avoids plutocracy.

Looking at the DAO's Gini coefficient, which measures the level of voting equality within a DAO, we see Pocket's unique structure has made it a positive outlier when examining equality.

7/ What has this unique structure meant for participation?

By introducing proof-of-participation friction, @POKTnetwork has been able to avoid the Sybil Problem.

While this has limited the number of new governance tokens minted, participation remains high. https://t.co/0GgMKWVbpL

6/ The @POKTnetwork governance process consists of three phases: preliminary discussion, off-chain voting, and Implementation.

With three proposal types: Pocket Improvement Proposals (PIPs), Pocket Ecosystem Proposals (PEPs), and Parameter Update Proposals (PUPs).

5/ Once a path is chosen, four steps must be completed.

After the steps are complete, the new POKTDAO token holders will be allowed to vote on @POKTnetwork DAO Snapshot votes.

4/ @POKTnetwork DAO utilizes a proof-of-participation mechanism to verify users are human.

In order to vote, users must follow one of the four paths allowing them to earn trophies and a POKTDAO token:

+App Developers
+Node Runners
+Community Shepherds
+Governor/Contributors

3/ The PNF executes governance transactions on the DAO‚Äôs behalf.

The PNC consists of POKTDAO token holders and is responsible for @POKTnetwork DAO‚Äôs legislative duties.

2/ @POKTnetwork DAO consists of three parties:

‚Ä¢ Legislative: Pocket Network Council (PNC)
‚Ä¢ Executive: Pocket Network Foundation (PNF)
‚Ä¢ Judiciary: Pocket Network validators

4/ A closer look at Decentralized cloud storage reveals its strengths and weaknesses.

Strengths:
+More Cost Effective
+Increased Data Security & Privacy
+Increased Redundancy

Weaknesses:
+Slower Retrieval Times
+Not Yet Proven to be Resilient
+High Learning Curve https://t.co/akUWLvPacl

3/ How is this possible?

Decentralized storage networks utilize blockchains to create a P2P network of storage nodes.

These networks leverage data retention, data durability and availability, persistence mechanisms, and data privacy and security mechanisms to maintain the data. https://t.co/VbhrWMX4Qi

2/Let's compare...

Traditional cloud storage requires massive, centralized data centers, which centralizes storage and creates costly barriers to entry.

Decentralized cloud storage eliminates single points of failure by leveraging unused storage capacity.

1/ @Google, @Amazon, and @Microsoft account for 66% of the cloud services industry, resulting in risks to data privacy, security, and integrity.

@Filecoin, @Sia__Foundation, @Storj, and @Arweave combats these risks, providing a better model for storing and accessing data.üßµ https://t.co/ynULaFMTSq

6/ For more on Usage-Based Governance with Sybil Resistance, check out the full report from @john_tv_locke.
https://t.co/6SreMraoFv

5/ Effective sybil resistance enables a one-human-one-vote governance system.

It makes the system more democratic, enabling equity based on humanity rather than resources.

4/ The second part of this formula is Sybil resistance.

To protect protocols from attackers looking to control entities, determining if each interacting entity has a unique owner or not is paramount. https://t.co/W5lSrG1CjA

3/ How can crypto do better?

Usage-based governance is a way to protect users from monopolies.

Usage-based governance creates a new playing field where investors have to work within the confines of direct user protection.

2/ Currently, dApp's use token-based governance to adjust protocol parameters. This approach allows monopolies to extract value from users.

The counterargument is that builders and devs create and manage networks at scale, and should be incentivized as they add value for users.

1/ The current state of dApp governance is highly investor-centric, giving users little representation.

The solution, usage-based governance with sybil resistance.üßµ https://t.co/Kl2hRZ1ToN

7/ Explore empirical evidence supporting the idea that the demand for security affects crypto network value and price in the full Enterprise report from @kunalgoel, "Layer-1 Value Thesis: The Expected Demand for Security Model (EDSM)".

https://t.co/kJYeuTzBc9

6/ ~Present and Future

Network value of the blockchain is affected by both present and future demand for security.

The speed of change in investors‚Äô expectation of future demand for security can effect crypto volatility. https://t.co/C8JIGqMYKu

5/ ~Key Driver

The demand for security from the blockchain and its supply must be in equilibrium.

If demand exceeds security, participants become uncomfortable with security guarantees.

If the security supplied exceeds demand, participants move towards excess security. https://t.co/EQPI1Zi5k4

4/ ~Infrastructure, Applications, Assets, and Users

The increase of any use cases on top of the blockchain increases the security demanded from it and, consequently, the value of its native asset.

As such, the model suggests a harmonious relationship between all participants. https://t.co/P7hYZRhTQP

3/ ~Gross Demand for Security

The model proposes that the demand for security is the key driver of price.

While the most quantifiable aspect of security demand is the commercial value or economic activity, security demand can also come from non-commercial activity.

2/ Let's break this down...

~Price of the Asset

The key role of market cap is to provide security.

Proof-of-Stake (PoS) networks are a good example in that the staked market cap directly impacts the cost of attacking the network.

To increase the security, price must increase.

1/ How should we model crypto's value?

The Expected Demand for Security Model proposes that the key driver for the price of a native blockchain asset is the gross demand for security by all present and future infrastructure, applications, assets, and users on its network.üßµ https://t.co/eT4a6ipJt7

8/ While both components of the PoR process can be completed without a third-party auditor, the average user may be unwilling to put in the effort.

Auditors contribute an objective, independent validation of a custodian‚Äôs assets and liabilities to complement the process.

7/ Both address the custodian‚Äôs root problem ‚Äî publicizing its liabilities while preserving customer privacy.

However, neither is a perfect solution and still presents opportunities for custodians to manipulate the system.

6/ How do custodians account for/match liabilities?

Custodians are naturally incentivized to under-report their liabilities if they are under-collateralized.

To prevent fraud, early adopters of PoR prove their liabilities to depositors through:

+List method
+Merkle tree method https://t.co/Z1Jg9ryTIM

5/ This process comes with two limitations.

First, there‚Äôs no definitive way for the exchange to prove that the private keys have not been shared or compromised.

Second, balances are only accounted for at a specific point in time (a ‚Äúsnapshot‚Äù).

4/ How do custodians account for on-chain assets?

For each unique asset (BTC, ETH, etc.), custodians aggregate their wallet balances and prove that they have control over the addresses using two methods:

+Private key signatures
+Rotating assets to predefined addresses https://t.co/MXTCT0xtUV

3/ "Proof of Solvency‚Äù (PoS) ‚â† Proof of Reserves (PoR).

+PoR doesn‚Äôt include off-chain assets or liabilities
+PoR is carried out at a specific point in time

Moving forward, custodians must account for and match on-chain assets with off-chain liabilities.

2/ Let's start by defining Proof of Reserves (PoR).

PoR is the process in which a custodian transparently attests its on-chain assets and equivalent proof that its outstanding liabilities to depositors do not exceed these reserve asset amounts. https://t.co/FC0vxjnGeV

1/ In the wake of the @FTX_Official fallout, market participants are demanding to see centralized custodians' balance sheets.

While this should hold custodians accountable, is it really that simple?üßµ https://t.co/Rs9b3Rt21m

Very high-importance proposals are rarely used but should be used when an issue directly impacts stakeholders or the DAO, particularly if it is a time-sensitive proposal.

Hack-related proposals fit this description.
https://t.co/z77wlR8Dqh

High-importance proposals signify significant spending from a DAO, major changes in the DAO structure or smart contracts, or exceptional proposals stakeholders should be aware of.

That includes changes like a tokenomics revamp or on-chain upgrade.
https://t.co/tZKspMfR6x

Medium-importance proposals signify substantial spending from a DAO, significant parameter changes, or uncommon decisions that are voted on but don't deeply impact the DAO or stakeholders.

DAO budget approvals would be included at this level.
https://t.co/w3JJgrKZmR

Low-importance proposals signify no action is needed, and there is no strong impact on stakeholders, the DAO itself, or day-to-day ops.

e.g. small parameter updates.

5/ MEV alters the networks downstream creating both positive and negative consequences.

4/ The MEV supply chain's actors interact with each other differently during each stage of a transaction's life cycle.

A transaction is created, searchers scan transactions for opportunities to profit, builders mark it for inclusion in a future block, and finally it's executed. https://t.co/nBv5FMOkRu

3/ Regardless of blockchain, the chain of actors that influence transactions in the presence of MEV typically include:

+Users
+Wallet
+Searcher
+Builder
+Security Provider

Depending on network maturity, work for intermediaries may be more specialized. https://t.co/svVUkjGyYL

2/ Blockchains require intermediaries to execute transactions on their behalf.

Intermediaries selectively insert, reorder, or censor user transaction requests to generate additional profit.

The process of selectively editing transactions is MEV.

4/ @OverlayProtocol's mint and burn structure has raised inflation concerns.

+Fees

3/ Simply put: $OVL dilution occurs when the protocol mints new tokens to pay out the trader‚Äôs profit.

2/ @OverlayProtocol's market functions very similarly to a perpetual futures market but instead of needing a buyer and seller, traders deposit $OVL into a long or short.

Additionally, Substream aids developers by providing composable maps and stores, heavy caching, and a more familiar language in RUST, allowing for shorter dev cycles.

Enter Firehose and Substream. 

Simply, Firehose extracts ALL data at speed. 

This allows for scalability, parallel compute, and reduced reliance on nodes.

But it isn‚Äôt perfect, indexing speed can be slow, leading to long development cycles. 

On top of that, subgraphs are not composable, meaning they cannot be stacked or integrated with one another.

Getting blockchain data is hard!

It‚Äôs raw, unprocessed, difficult to access, and slow.

Enter the collaboration with @graphprotocol, aimed at solving issues tied to data consistency and availability.

Our Quarterly structure is segmented into: 

+Protocol Primer
+Qualitative Analysis
+Quantitative Analysis
+Governance 
+Notable Events
+Financial Performance
+Operational Performance

Each section is built out with real-time data collected through our tools and libraries.

How are we scaling these reports?

Our inaugural @compoundfinance quarterly dropped in Q3 21‚Äô. 

This has since grown to close to 40 quarterly reports in the most recent quarter, spanning different chains and sectors.

Why can‚Äôt a protocol do this themselves? It‚Äôs really hard. 

The quarterly reports are a collaboration between our data scientists, research analysts, and the protocols involved.

We are providing transparency and data standardization through our product suite and Quarterly reports.

These reports are the fiduciary responsibility to their communities and the crypto ecosystem.

4/ To decentralize the governance of dAPIs and of the project as a whole, @API3DAO is governed by a non-profit DAO. 

The API3 DAO oversees the entire network and is responsible for steering and executing the API3 project. https://t.co/JAXkQ0mwVy

3/ The native token, $API3, is used for two main purposes:

+Governance
+Staking

Tokenholders who stake their API3 receive a pro-rata share of the protocol staking rewards. 

These rewards are paid in exchange for taking the risk of slashing should dAPI malfunctions occur.

2/ To accommodate developers' needs, API3 has a modular design with three layers built on top of each other:

+Protocol layer
+Middle layer
+Top layer.

Depending on development needs, a dApp can consume API3 services at each of the three layers. https://t.co/QHodHaf3Xv

1/ @API3DAO differentiates itself from existing oracle solutions by providing full transparancy data feeds to its consumers and on-chain service coverage in the event of API malfunctions.

So how does the technology behind API3 work? https://t.co/X1DrPwMysC

4/ As rollups handle more activity, base layer @ethereum will be implementing danksharding to scale horizontally to support more DA throughput.

7/ Fraxlend allows users to create a borrowing market between any pair of ERC-20 tokens that have a @chainlink data feed.

6/ Leveraging Fraxswap gives @fraxfinance more granular control over its monetary policy.

5/ Fraxswap is the first live implementation of a TWAMM. 

This AMM functions the same as a standard AMM, allowing anyone to permissionlessly trade against it or provide liquidity, while also allowing traders to process long-term orders in a cost-effective manner. https://t.co/3zEaFZKYJz

7/ swNFT holds information about the stake, linking it to the yield earned by the initial ETH deposited to the node operator. 

In order to actually receive the rewards (and principal), users need to burn the swNFT with the initial deposited $swETH amount.

6/ $swETH is a non-rebasing, ERC-20, liquid staking derivative token representing the principal stake. 

Once liquid staking (withdrawals) goes live, stakers will have the option to use swETH across DeFi.

5/ In this model, the stake isn‚Äôt naturally liquid since it‚Äôs tied to a particular node operator.

@swellnetworkio has found a way to mitigate this by abstracting away the deposited $ETH from the staking yield by using the $swETH derivative and the swNFT. https://t.co/ydGXbm0Dpd

4/ Since @swellnetworkio uses atomic deposits, users delegate stake (a minimum of 1 $ETH) directly into a Beacon Chain deposit contract of their choice. 

In other words, users can choose their node operator and continue to track their deposit. https://t.co/hWlgUMUlSj

3/ @swellnetworkio's node operator set is represented by two groups, verified and independent operators.

Node operators will set their commission rate, the amount of additional yield sent to their Swell fee pool, and how their returns are displayed, creating an open marketplace.

2/ So how does @swellnetworkio work? 

At a very high-level Swell operates quite differently from other Ethereum liquid staking protocols. https://t.co/WPKfSa61B1

1/ While the current set of non-custodial liquid staking protocols has been successful, there is still room for development.

@swellnetworkio believes it has learned from its competitors, offering a new way for $ETH holders to stake and earn a yield in @Ethereum. üßµ https://t.co/IAuB59KKOM

5/ While monolithic chains have a higher cost of hardware than modular chains, the difference is much less than it was a few years ago.

4/ What is the answer for monolithic scaling? 

While a monolithic chain could run on a single powerful computer (not realistic), the hope is that more nodes can be added, and the cost of the hardware needed to run a full node comes down, adding more computers to the network. https://t.co/iulKXKiHZp

3/ While most monolithic chains are capable of handling straightforward functions, issues can arise when you try to add more complex transactions.

This is the argument for modular blockchains. By segmenting these functions they can be individually optimized. https://t.co/MEvo5UCtQY

2/ Lets start with the key components of a blockchain. Blockchain components can be broken down into security, execution, and data availability. 

Monolithic chains have one set of validators securing each function while modular chains have a different set for each sub-function. https://t.co/Nb5ua0eV4y

5/ Both SFA and BME address the velocity problem and create a relationship between network usage and the token price.

The downside to this relationship is that if network usage declines, so would the price of the token.

4/ The most popular token models are the Burn-and-Mint Equilibrium model and the Stake-for-Access model. 

Essentially, the BME model works by translating protocol usage into token buying pressure while the SFA model translates network participation into token buying pressure. https://t.co/AsJh6oOJNF

3/ When it comes to value accrual, token price is driven by two components: speculative and fundamental.

For a protocol's token to capture value, well-designed tokenomics are essential. https://t.co/9kCCNPEj8M

2/ Investors believe that if token supply is fixed, price will increase as demand increases. 

However, this doesn't account for velocity. The longer the token is held, the higher the price. 

To solve this problem, protocols implement additional utilities, sinks, and incentives.

1/ While #Web3 infrastructure protocols have succeeded at value creation, they all face the challenge of aligning the usage of their networks with the token price.

8/ As regulatory pressure increases, protocols will likely begin focusing on further decentralizing their networks.

Do Ankr and Pocket Solve Web3‚Äôs Node Centralization Problems? Explore the full Pro report from @Old_Samster.

https://t.co/kKBoLQ7mQH

7/ @POKTnetwork appears to be further along than @ankr in terms of decentralization, maturity, and in the number of network participants. 

Pocket has over 37,000 independently operated nodes distributed around the globe, whereas Ankr only has 345 centrally operated nodes.

6/ But Are @ankr and @POKTnetwork Truly Decentralized?

Both Ankr and Pocket have similar network architectures:

+Applications send a relay request to the protocols
+Relays flow through a centralized, off-chain relay distributor https://t.co/rGZ0914ust

5/ @ankr and @POKTnetwork are two node infrastructure protocols working to address these centralization issues. 

The three main advantages of using a decentralized infrastructure protocol include: 

+Reduced cost
+Increased redundancy
+Censorship resistance

4/ Both centralized and decentralized nodes have their tradeoffs. 

Because decentralized networks rely on a handful of cloud providers, the network as a whole is more fragile. 

Protocols that rely on centralized infrastructure are more susceptible to censorship and outages.

3/ Centralized Infrastructure-as-a-Service businesses (e.g., @infura_io and @AlchemyPlatform) tend to rely on a single cloud provider. 

As a result, nodes have become centralized on the servers of a handful of large cloud providers. https://t.co/3NjjEhAACJ

2/ An RPC is an application programming interface (API) interaction that allows applications to communicate with servers on a shared network. 

RPC nodes enable decentralized apps to communicate with blockchains, which is essential for querying info and performing transactions.

1/ Following the @TornadoCash sanctions, the two largest node infrastructure providers, @infura_io  and @AlchemyPlatform, both deactivated their RPC links used in @TornadoCash's front end.

5/ Data availability is a rather complex problem without putting strain on full nodes.

Explore the full Pro report from @eshita on the Progression of the Data Availability Problem and The Data Availability Players. 

https://t.co/rrtIYY37TK

4/ Off-chain DA yields higher throughput at the expense of lowered security. 

Validiums guarantee DA off-chain through the use of data availability committees (DAC). 

DAC can be as small as 5 participants, leading to significant risks.

3/ Since it is not efficient to have full nodes download the entire block history, Simple DA sampling was introduced.

Through data redundancy, intricate sampling ensures operators cannot suppress data from the rest of the network.

2/ Regardless of the sequencer capacity or rollup throughput, the optimal DA layer must handle the high amount of data the sequencer will deposit on it, limiting scalability. 

Scalable DA can dissolve the need to consider these trade-offs when building a blockchain system. https://t.co/EcgDRU3xAF

1/ @ethereum  is the choice for the Data Availability (DA) layer for rollups, but its throughput is still limited.

4/ ~Application-Level Coin Mixers

Coin mixers group a bunch of transactions into a block and remove the link between senders and receivers.

Taking an alternate approach from its BTC-based predecessors, @Ethereum's @TornadoCash is instead built and deployed on the app layer. https://t.co/4uQBg6xfSP

3/ ~Private Payment Platforms

In a private transaction, the sender, receiver, and sometimes the amount transferred is hidden on the public blockchain ledger. 

The first implementation of privacy on the blockchain came in the form of standalone privacy-oriented networks. https://t.co/6SsWTBJFTr

2/ Currently, there are three main technologies in the crypto space to enable user privacy:

+Privacy-focused payment networks
+Application level privacy mixers
+Programmable privacy on Layer-2 scaling solutions https://t.co/yuS0Sd9eYa

6/  Each of the solutions announced represents meaningful progress in the journey towards a full zkEVM.

https://t.co/gM77SCklTo

5/ The rollup landscape is heating up with new runtime models, optimistic rollups, zk-rollups, and now zkEVMs. 

All three projects recently announced their projects are on testnets and that we will start seeing mainnet launches at the end of the year. https://t.co/1k7jw3S351

4/ The optimal zkEVM solution would be a bytecode (compiled Solidity code) compatible zkEVM, making the transition for developers seamless. 

A less ideal solution would be a language-level compatible EVM, transpiling Solidity into code that a non-EVM virtual machine can read.

3/ The EVM runtime was not built to support ZKPs, which is the gap that zkEVM projects are working diligently to close.

A zkEVM would support the same smart contract capabilities as @ethereum, allowing developers to move any contract from Ethereum L1 directly to a zkEVM.

2/ Each zkEVM plans to operate as a Layer-2 (L2) rollup. 

An L2 rollup batches user transactions together for cheaper gas costs and faster local processing while preserving the security guarantees of L1. 

There are two main types of rollups: 

+Optimistic
+Zero-knowledge (zk) https://t.co/1sRJto2NhU

1/ This week brought three separate announcements by @0xPolygon, @Scroll_ZKP, and @zksync. 

All three projects are approaching building zkEVMs (zero-knowledge @ethereum Virtual Machines) differently, with tradeoffs for each design.

Let's explore The Big Three zkEVMs. https://t.co/oy7ZTagvHq

5/ The LN allows node operators to put bitcoin to work to earn fees from routing transactions and providing inbound liquidity to users and merchants. 

This yield generation strategy is highly liquid, has no direct counterparty risk, and is non-custodial.

4/ With that said, the two primary methods of earning on the LN are through:

+Routing Fees: Fees earned by node operators for forwarding a payment
+Channel Lease Fees: Fees earned from providing inbound liquidity to nodes

Chart via- @ambosstech https://t.co/XuJBVCbiyS

3/ In order for a user to begin receiving Lightning payments, they need to source or lease inbound liquidity from another node or service provider.

This is a fundamental limitation of the protocol since it requires additional complex steps in order to get a node up and running.

2/ On LN, users don‚Äôt need to have a direct channel in order to send or receive a payment. 

The network automatically determines the cheapest, fastest, and most reliable path available to route a payment. 

In exchange for routing a payment, nodes can charge a fee. https://t.co/5s5vF3bTxA

1/ @Bitcoin can be put to work in a Lightning node where fees can be generated from routing transactions and selling liquidity.

6/ While dVPNs may still be a small layer in the rapidly growing Web3 infrastructure sector, its similarity to larger projects like @helium and @Filecoin should be noted.

Explore the full Pro report on Decentralized VPNs from @kaushikvg.

https://t.co/Isvbgaq7Vx

5/ Most of the dVPNs listed don‚Äôt release very detailed network statistics. 

However, one of the leading software dVPNs, Sentinel, showed 55,537 active nodes in June 2022, a 21% increase from May 2022, and a 5,859% increase from July 2021, where there were only 932 active nodes. https://t.co/ePEbnSDVhl

4/ With hardware dVPNs, users purchase an all-in-one device that allows them to operate a node and also utilize the dVPN, the downside being the need for the hardware. 

Alternatively, software dVPNs allow anyone to use them as long as they pay for the service.

3/ There are numerous dVPN projects all at different stages in the development process with different network architectures, services, features, and reward mechanisms. 

However, the biggest differentiator between dVPNs is the type: hardware or software.

2/ dVPNs are pretty similar to VPNs, but they do have a few differences:

+Incentivization ‚Äî node operators earn token rewards for bandwidth
+Pay structures ‚Äî one-time (Hardware) vs pay-as-you-go (Software)

6/ Recently, @arbitrum saw a spike in gas fees due to its rollout of the Odyssey program.

At one point, the price of a single swap reached $6.19 compared to $5.36 on @ethereum. 

This event questioned the ability of Arbitrum to cheaply scale throughput.

5/ Modular rollups make settlement optional. 

Sovereign rollups were conceptualized when @CelestiaOrg was introduced, which is a modular data availability and consensus layer. 

Sovereign rollups do not use a monolithic L1 to settle on; rather, they settle on their own. https://t.co/371f7PJ4xO

4/ There are two main categories: validity and fraud proofs.

+Validity Proof Rollups
+Fraud Proof Rollups

Rollups share @ethereum for gas and are at risk of experiencing the same fate as congested L1s, however a single system can have more than one rollup.

3/ Top-down, rollups can be separated by whether they post validated proofs on a smart contract settlement layer or not. 

Settlement provides objective finality that the processed transactions are valid and ordered correctly. https://t.co/lrecZTy8Kb

2/ Rollups allow for scalability on the L1 by batching transactions from the L1 and executing them on an L2, output is sent back to the L1. 

The type of rollup can be classified by how transactions are validated and where data availability (DA) takes place.

1/ Created to scale throughput, rollups continue to settle on monolithic L1s like @ethereum  ‚Äî however, as usage increases, will rollups remain cheap to use?

As expected, $COMP token incentives fell by 66% in Q2, compared to 52% in Q1. https://t.co/hUehdo3xT4

6/ In Q2, liquidations grew to $229 million, up from $134 million in Q1. 

This activity was fueled by liquidations across the $WBTC and $WETH markets resulting in increases of 687% and 56%, respectively. https://t.co/chPE1NpZxm

5/ @compoundfinance's aggregate utilization ratio has declined rapidly, shedding 35% year-to-date. 

In Q2, utilization saw its lowest at 27.3%, coinciding with fears of a recession and the overall market experiencing turmoil. https://t.co/RM2bZNr2uX

4/ Annualized borrower interest rates peaked to 4.32% at the beginning of Q2 then bottomed out at 2.21% towards the end of the quarter. 

The cost of borrowing is directly correlated with the decline in loan demand and the bearish sentiment felt across the crypto market. https://t.co/NvmOJ1MgF0

3/ Outstanding loans declined 77% from $3.5 billion in Q1 to a modest $812 million in Q2 while deposits declined 70% from $9.7 billion to ~$3 billion.

Despite the declining financial figures in Q2, the increased liquidations allowed @compoundfinance net income to still grow 11%. https://t.co/ENERYkQz4D

2/ @compoundfinance is a leading interest rate protocol that enables users to permissionlessly borrow and lend assets from a pool of collateral. 

The interest rates for these assets are set algorithmically using an interest rate model based on the proportion of assets lent out.

1/ This report dives deep into @compoundfinance's Q2 presenting a performance analysis, qualitative analysis, and @compoundfinance's roadmap moving forward.

6/ @compoundfinance's decline has been exacerbated due to users settling into their preferred protocol.

5/ @compoundfinance significantly underperformed the other protocols in the sector ‚Äî especially in the key customer segments. 

Across all segments, Compound experienced nearly an 80% decline in new borrow volumes from H1 2021 to H2 2022. https://t.co/nBeHYKEfWX

4/ To segment lending users, each address can be labeled based on their lifetime borrows across all three major @ethereum lending protocols.

Smaller users with smaller borrow amounts decreased the most while the larger users showed more resiliency. https://t.co/oiIiaZlCL7

3/ However, the picture isn‚Äôt as bleak as the user decline would suggest. 

Splitting the user base between smaller users who borrowed less than $100,000 and larger users shows the unique user decline is largely driven by the smaller users.

2/ @compoundfinance, @MakerDAO, and @AaveAave  (specifically V2 on @ethereum) are the top lending protocols. 

Together, they have seen the weekly unique addresses depositing and borrowing decline since coming out of DeFi summer in 2021.

6/ @ethereum in its current form is semi-modular as we approach The Merge because of the introduction of L2s into the ecosystem. 

L2s provide the ability to move computation off-chain in order to increase throughput of the base layer. https://t.co/zX48VmfuGg

5/ @CelestiaOrg is a ledger that doesn‚Äôt validate transactions but stores whatever is posted to it. 

It is a separate data availability and consensus layer, which depends on a rollup for execution.

4/ EVM has its limitations when it comes to storage and pre-built functions. 

Modular execution environments are also being developed in order to bestow more customizability for blockchain developers.

This allows for increased dev experimentation with Execution environments.

3/ Monolithic chains face the blockchain trilemma where it can sufficiently optimize for 2 out 3 when it comes to security, scalability, and decentralization. 

Let‚Äôs look into the current landscape of the modular stack and how it outperforms the monolithic model üëá

2/ The basic purpose of a blockchain is to keep an honest, immutable ledger of transactions or data. 

It is composed of a few crucial pieces to keep this ledger verified and growing. Abstracted away, there are three main functions: 

+Consensus
+Data availability
+Execution.

3/ One of the best ways to monitor the profile of outstanding debt and its potential effects is through the liquidation distribution. 

The liquidation distribution aggregates debt positions and plots outstanding debt at each position‚Äôs liquidation point.

+Gossip protocol
+Virtual voting

Together these components help to achieve its high TPS rate and fair ordering of transactions.

3/ @hedera's Hashgraph is a data structure and consensus algorithm. Hedera features two types of nodes that form the Hedera network: 

+Consensus
+Mirror nodes

2/ On a blockchain, transaction data exists in a string of blocks validated by nodes on the network.

6/ Relative valuations can help find potential mismatches in value and price without personal bias and with limited exposure to broad market risk.

For more, explore the full Enterprise report on The Theory of Relativity from 
@kunalgoel. 

https://t.co/33WFErBSqW

5/ The most important benefit of using relative valuations is that it reduces market risk by helping create delta-neutral strategies. 

In uncertain times, when the market is extremely volatile, relative valuations can still be used to generate returns with limited market risk.

4/ As an example when comparing their current position to their 180-day averages; we notice that BTC/ETH has moved much further up than $DOGE/ $SHIB in the recent crash. 

This mismatch would suggest that $BTC and/or $SHIB are currently overvalued compared to $ETH and/or $DOGE. https://t.co/Wgh7pg8TMI

3/ We can explore different categories of Layer-1s and compare their valuation in terms of each other and in terms of other related protocols.

Relative valuations can help investors create long-short positions that are neutral to market risk but still able to generate returns.

2/ The key problem is that Layer-1s do not interact with fiat as a part of their business operations. 

Their revenue and their costs are denominated in the native token. 

As the price of the token changes in fiat terms, the profitability of the blockchain also changes.

1/ Layer-1s are hard to value in absolute terms as they operate within an independent system, generating flows only in their native currencies.

So how can we come up with accurate valuations?

@LARamon2 @StarkWareLtd The image is simply a depiction of how batched transactions work via ZK Rollups. As far as potential security risks, rollups derive their security from ETH Mainnet. If you believe Mainnet to be secure the same should hold true for rollups.

7/ Optimistic and ZK-rollups' beaming advantage is that they solve @ethereum's scalability problem without compromising security and decentralization. 

For more, explore the full Pro report on @ethereum's Rollup-Centric Future from @0xallyzach. 

https://t.co/dYldV9BbcQ

6/ Danksharding is what makes the Rollup-Centric Roadmap feasible. 

It turns Ethereum into a settlement and data availability layer and places scalability in the hands of Layer-2 rollups.

5/ Sharding is a horizontal on-chain scaling solution that increases the amount of activity the chain can efficiently process. 

Each shard will operate with a subset of nodes that will check data availability.

4/ Zero-knowledge (ZK)-rollups, like @StarkWareLtd, are similar to Optimistic rollups in that they combine a large number of off-chain transactions and submit a batched version back to Mainnet. 

However, ZK-rollups use validity proofs to validate transactions instantly. https://t.co/LLmNBkYdne

3/ Optimistic rollups, like @arbitrum or @optimismPBC, assume all transactions are valid from the get-go. 

To secure these transactions, they provide a challenge period where verifiers can dispute a transaction's legitimacy through a fraud-proof on the parent chain. https://t.co/XZ8J4bQoji

2/ Rollups are the most prominent Layer-2 scaling solution in the space. 

They can be classified by their validation and data storage methods. 

All rollups aggregate mass transaction data off-chain into batches and publish results back to the mainnet through consensus.

1/  As it prepares for The Merge, @ethereum is pivoting to a "Rollup-Centric Roadmap." 

It plans to combine the best of on-chain and off-chain scaling solutions.

Let‚Äôs explore @ethereum's Rollup-Centric Future in this report from @0xallyzach. üßµ

Typically, the network would have a challenge period, but as the network remains in development, fraud proofs have not been enabled.

8/ Understanding the true market cap of a crypto protocol is key before making any investment decision, as it provides the odds of success for the investment.

Check out the full Analyst Note on Market Cap and FDV from @kunalgoel.

https://t.co/XEUfXOGtI4

7/ This overcomes the limitations of fully diluted valuation.

If any entity can capture the true market cap, they do not need to separately buy the tokens held in the treasury as they will also be the sole owner of the treasury and its assets.

6/ Learning from the above, the true market cap for crypto should be the dollar amount needed to own the protocol entirely.

Translating to crypto, it would typically mean owning the fully diluted or max supply less the supply held in the protocol treasury. https://t.co/3e8C4ZkORr

5/ In crypto, there has been no consensus on defining market capitalization.

Generally, there are a few different types of supply used in the crypto market including:

+Circulating supply
+Fully diluted supply or max supply https://t.co/B24o1QC8MM

4/ The theory of reflexivity says that market caps can even drive fundamentals creating a self-fulfilling prophecy of better performance.

A company with a higher market cap is better positioned to attract and retain talent, and can use its higher market cap to acquire companies.

3/ In the case of investing, market cap are these odds.

For example, if an investor buys Tesla at a market cap of $1 trillion instead of Toyota at a market cap of $250 billion, Tesla must not just outperform Toyota but to do it by four times. https://t.co/wjUlBaSQci

2/ In traditional finance, a company's market cap is the dollar value of its outstanding shares of stock.

In other words, the market cap is the price at which the company can be fully bought.

1/ Market capitalization is a key fundamental metric for investments but is often not well understood.

6/ When it comes to social platforms on Web3, @ceramicnetwork is one of the first full-fledged infrastructures to make a good developer and user experience possible.

Check out the full Pro report on @ceramicnetwork from @eshita.

https://t.co/kuNYIk2ukw

5/ @ceramicnetwork employs the Decentralized identity (DID) standard developed by W3, which is an identifier separate from any centralized registries that prove a person's identity.

Every transaction or update to a data stream is authenticated by a user‚Äôs (account‚Äôs) DID. https://t.co/WeOB87WgCJ

4/ Each user is represented by an account in @ceramicnetwork and is tied to streams that represent their data.

State changes only have to do with individual accounts which transition independent of all other accounts and cannot modify another account, but can link to them. https://t.co/2LPjjRfz9V

3/ @ceramicnetwork is built upon the IPFS protocol which has a content-based naming system for files stored across its network. 

Though IPFS runs separately from Ceramic, each Ceramic node connects to an IPFS node over HTTP. https://t.co/IUatmHXwV8

2/ A data stream is an instance of the @ceramicnetwork that is modified when a transaction is signed by the account owner or user. 

Data models, or collections of streams, are used to represent a feature on a platform and these are collected to produce a Ceramic app. https://t.co/8xHsamzn23

1/ @ceramicnetwork is building a system to store mutable smart documents on-chain, which allows developers to build quicker and provide richer user experiences.

7/ @BreederDodo was developed to address capital inefficiencies in traditional AMM-based DEXs. 

Check out the full report on @BreederDodo from @hsxhuang. 

https://t.co/w7chofJOrv

6/ @BreederDodo is the only DEX that uses PMM, theoretically resulting in comparative advantage in capital efficiency. 

One measure of capital efficiency is the liquidity turnover rate (LTR), trading volume/TVL. 

A higher LTR indicates better capital efficiency. https://t.co/HpbZHA85YK

5/ Total value locked (TVL) across all of @BreederDodo's DEXs on all chains is $140.54 million.

DODO has the opportunity to expand its community as they expand to more chains this year, including @avalancheavax, @BobaCommunity, @FantomFDN, @neonlabsorg/@solana, & @optimismPBC.

3/ @BreederDodo uses a proactive market maker (PMM) algorithm, which is a market-making mechanism that anticipates market/economic shifts & makes adjustments accordingly. 

The protocol enjoys impressive capital efficiency allowing DODO to minimize slippage & impermanent loss.

2/ @BreederDodo has two main functions: 

+Facilitating peer-to-pool trading between users on its own platform.
+Aggregating liquidity from other sources to match buy and sell orders.

1/ @BreederDodo has entered the decentralized exchange (DEX) landscape as the only proactive market maker (PMM).

Holders can lock their $ALPACA for up to one year and receive xALPACA in return. 

xALPACA increases with lock duration & represents a holder‚Äôs share of the governance rewards pool and voting power. https://t.co/hMPctjmXNF

6/ @AlpacaFinance's Automated Vaults have stayed oversubscribed. 

The eight vaults, at or near capacity as of this writing, have almost $150 million in total value locked (TVL).

5/ @AlpacaFinance's core function is to allow users to yield farm certain pools with leverage.

The maximum leverage available on the platform is 6x, but the upper limit varies by pool. 

These integrations & parameters are currently decided upon & set by the Alpaca Finance team.

4/ $AUSD is a fork of @MakerDAO, & is a decentralized, overcollateralized stablecoin.

Lenders can collateralize their ibTokens (e.g., $BNB) to permissionlessly mint (borrow) $AUSD.

This system unlocks capital efficiency by allowing lenders to earn interest on their collateral.

3/ @AlpacaFinance allows lenders to earn interest by depositing assets into their respective vaults. 

These assets are then offered to leveraged yield farmers as undercollateralized loans that can only be used on the platform.

2/ @AlpacaFinance mirrors a common two-sided market, with lenders and borrowers. 

There are a number of features & products working with & around this process to bolster capital efficiency, safety & ease of use. https://t.co/Z4w7FKMpcV

8/ The proposed changes to the @helium Network‚Äôs architecture & economic model are substantial changes to the protocol. 

Check out the full Pro report on @helium from @Old_Samster. 

https://t.co/ib4esNtF4y

7/ HIP 51 also proposes a new governance mechanism which introduces a vote-escrow weighted governance model for HNT (veHNT). 

This model is very similar to @CurveFinance's governance mechanism which can be read about below:
https://t.co/3FI5dh6C4Z

6/ The subDAO layer is where all the magic actually happens. 

HIP 51 specifies that all subDAOs must operate Oracles for their network. 

The motivation behind each subDAO having its own DNT is to give ‚Äúfull control over DNT issuance parameters". https://t.co/a3dck8MZbm

5/ The proposal aims to address two problems, namely blockchain scalability & subnetwork incentive alignment, while adding numerous benefits which include:

+ Increased Resiliency

+ Increased Efficiency

+ More Partnerships

4/ Under this new network structure, the subDAOs would each have their own Decentralized Network Token (DNT).

Each DNT would serve as the core economic & governance unit of the subnetwork, allowing each protocol to manage its PoC rules, data transfer pricing, and miner rewards.

3/ HIP 51 makes two proposals:

+ The existing @helium Network should become a Layer-1, known as the Helium DAO.

+ Each Decentralized Network Protocol (DNP) such as LoRaWAN, 5G, & WiFi, should become an independent network Oracle (similar to a Layer-2), referred to as a subDAO. https://t.co/D67c8PDJY3

2/ For @helium to scale beyond a LoRaWAN network, the network‚Äôs construction & economic model must change. 

Transitioning the network‚Äôs architecture away from a monolithic blockchain to a modular blockchain structure would allow any type of telecom network to launch on Helium.

1/ @helium's goal is to replicate the IoT network‚Äôs success onto numerous other telecom networks including 5G, WiFi, VPN, and CDN.

8/ Are we out of the woods yet?

See what @dunleavy89, @chasedevens, @Saypien_, and @john_tv_locke have to say about @terra_money's $UST in the full Pro Report. 

https://t.co/cx9tPkmd1d

7/ @LFG_org, the organization created to defend the peg, mobilized its reserves during this episode. 

All of the roughly 80,000 $BTC were sold & or loaned out to market makers to provide $UST liquidity at key levels.

6/ On Saturday, @CurveFinance's key pools started to diverge from equilibrium suggesting traders were selling $UST & LPs were pulling at-risk capitaI. 

The trend accelerated on Monday, when the $UST-3pool was almost entirely drained of counter-side liquidity with $UST at +95%. https://t.co/BISXHJbiqS

5/ Amidst a broader market selloff, the large & sudden $UST supply introduction created reflexive sell pressure on $LUNA which culminated in the de-pegging event.

Large amounts of capital were deployed at $0.98 to protect the peg, but reflexive selling accelerated.

4/ With a supply outflow this large, pressure would be put on critical peg stabilization junctures like @CurveFinance.

7/ @DeriProtocol's integrated Power Perpetuals contracts provide an asymmetric advantage to longs by boosting their upside profit and mitigating downside loss.

A use case Deri has adopted for Power Perpetuals is hedging against impermanent loss.

6/ @DeriProtocol integrated a Greek-based margin system for Everlasting Options.

The Greeks allow the protocol to estimate the rate of change of the options position value due to the price change of the underlying asset.

5/ @DeriProtocol also introduced the Vault, a smart contract within the DPMM that interacts with external custodians. 

With the integration of the Vault protocol, Deri can accurately pull the data of each user‚Äôs multi-base-token balance and retain real-time effective value. https://t.co/NIwmvuL0w1

4/ @DeriProtocol has simplified the DPMM network architecture by providing a single liquidity pool.

Upgrades to the DPMM architecture include:

+Uniform DPMM
+The Vault & external custody
+Greek-based Everlasting Options
+Power Perpetuals derivatives

4/ The @optimismPBC Foundation runs the single centralized sequencer.

6/ DAOs have several strategies to maintain some stability in their reserves. 

Learn more about The Health of DAO Treasuries the full Pro article from @eshita and continue to follow #DAODeepDives!

https://t.co/jN3TuhvKgr

5/ To realize how well the DAO is stacking its assets, it is important to take a look at its holdings without the native asset. 

In @Uniswap's case, they essentially hold 0% in non-native tokens. 

In the event that a native token crashes, a DAO is put in a precarious place. https://t.co/EW9C2dyFAk

4/ Looking at the overall treasury composition of the 15 largest DAOs, there are 3 distinct parts: 

+ Native asset
+ Deposits in other protocols
+ Other assets

Holding large sums of the native token means that price changes can affect the treasury value massively. https://t.co/ulvbNHHiMQ

3/ The top 15 treasuries today hold over $7 billion together, which is about 60% of all value in DAO treasuries.

The remaining 40% is held by thousands of other DAOs holding small amounts individually. https://t.co/NFXuOYImH8

2/ A DAO can instate several types of tokens including governance, utility, and non-transferrable governance tokens (DXdao reputation token).

DAOs typically hold mostly governance tokens in addition to perhaps bluechip tokens until scaling demands the need to start diversifying.

1/ DAO treasuries today cumulatively hold over $11 billion in value. From the start and end of 2021, this number grew 40x.

Initially focused on investments and protocol governance, DAO use cases have expanded to include open-source NFT governance, social clubs, and media. https://t.co/mlYJUtMpmc

6/ In the switch to proof of stake, stakers put up capital (like a bond principal) in exchange for a return. 

If we are comparing @ethereum to an equity or a bond, a key difference is cash is distributed to stakeholders on a set schedule.

5/ A regime shift to a new environment with a higher persistent level of inflation makes bonds & gold less attractive. 

The @ethereum merge creates conditions for $ETH as a quasi-government bond & further solidifies the narrative for @bitcoin as digital gold.

4/ Correlations are affected by the prevailing inflation backdrop of the economy. 

The correlation between stocks and bonds has been negative since 2000 but prior to that period, the last time the correlation was negative was the 1950s. https://t.co/QIjiByxT2A

3/ The historical relationship of negative correlation between stocks & these risk-off assets is becoming less reliable. 

Gold fell in the pandemic sell-off of March 2020 & was flat during the most recent market drop in Q1 2022. 

Holding bonds didn't help in either. https://t.co/9kKDpIa37R

2/ US government bonds & gold have had a persistent low or negative correlation to US stocks.

These two asset classes have consistently moved independently from US stocks for 20+ years. https://t.co/3NUpJPiae9

1/ Historically, there has been a strong correlation between $ETH, $BTC, & the broader US stock market (Nasdaq & S&P 500). 

The correlation averages 40‚Äì50% over longer rolling periods & up to 90% in shorter rolling periods, particularly during times of market stress. https://t.co/hHd6Zwjidr

6/ The PCV shrunk in value by 12.3% in Q1.

2/ In Q1, the reserve ratio dropped below 1 in January. It did correspond w/ downward pressure on the peg & redemptions of $FEI for PCV.

7/ To combat inflation, the Fed is clearly going to hike short-term rates in 2022 & hike them by a lot. 

But they are also going to stop purchasing treasuries, mortgage-backed securities (MBS), & treasury inflation-protected securities (TIPS) as part of quantitative tightening.

6/ Money printing has been bandied about as the cause of inflation before, but there wasn‚Äôt inflation after the 2008 crisis. 

Why not? Pretty simple, there were no direct stimulus payments to individuals. 

This time around, we had $2T pumped directly into the hands of spenders. https://t.co/J0qJV3RdJu

5/ Inflation determines where rates will go in the short and medium-term.

Consumer Price Index (CPI) is the one you hear about most often from major press outlets.

We currently stand at 8.5% on the Year-over-Year (YoY) headline inflation figures. https://t.co/CIT2TCyPwr

4/ Generally, hiking rates will slow down the economy, settling down price pressures.

Within the next year, the market is predicting the Fed will take some drastic measures to curb inflation. 

The market is pricing in a 74% chance of TEN rate hikes by the end of 2022. https://t.co/34K97PU0qM

3/ The chart below shows where we stand as of mid-April: flat but certainly not inverted in what has been the most predictive part of the yield curve. 

No recession impending from this indicator. 

The 3m & 10-year curve is actually the steepest it's been since 2017. https://t.co/QJkZWmCU2t

2/ The most important yield curve to watch is the difference between the 3-month (3m) & 10-year tenors. 

All eight times the 10-year flipped with the 3m since WWII, there was a recession within roughly 12 to 18 months. 

Just so we're clear, recessions are bad for risk assets. https://t.co/4wnCO7QSCj

1/ Yield curve inversions, balance sheet runoff, rate hikes, record inflation ‚Äî the 2022 macro landscape is in full-on crazy mode.

What‚Äôs going on, & how can this information be used to make some educated guesses on where we could be headed next? https://t.co/GuOEeRj5sv

6/ Peer-to-protocol mechanism designs have distinct tradeoffs compared to their peer-to-peer counterparts. 

The programmatic design of peer-to-protocol services like @JPEGd_69 & others has an effectively instantaneous time-to-liquidity at the cost of customizability.

5/ The protocol‚Äôs token distribution is split between 4 parties: the team, the DAO, the advisors, & the public. 

The advisory group includes a notable mix of both pseudonymous & publicly known angel investors: DCInvestor, DeFiGod, Santiago Santos, Tetranode, The LAO, and others. https://t.co/EBdsbluUdW

4/ Holders of whitelisted collections can automatically borrow up to 32% of their collateral value in $PUSd stablecoins. 

If the loan-to-value ratio goes above this number, users' collateral will be at risk of liquidation. https://t.co/e4fW2EFRlx

3/ Instead of a specific counterparty underwriting loans, the @JPEGd_69 protocol automatically underwrites loans based on a customizable set of parameters. 

These dynamic parameters include collection type, maximum loan-to-value (LTV) ratio, interest rates, & more. https://t.co/QVnree4zJ5

2/ @JPEGd_69 takes a peer-to-protocol lending approach similar to what‚Äôs seen in the fungible token space. 

Borrowers can create what JPEG‚Äôd calls ‚Äúnon-fungible debt positions‚Äù (NFDPs) by depositing their collateral to mint the protocol‚Äôs stablecoin, $PUSd.

8/ To better understand how value is created in the NFT market check out the full Pro article from @chasedevens. 

https://t.co/pgK8mO7ZHr

7/ The prominence of vintage markets proves that a luxury good‚Äôs value can increase with its age.

Despite the short history of NFTs, this phenomenon has already affected the market. The popularity of CryptoPunks is primarily due to the collection being one of the first.

6/ Luxury goods also derive value from their limited quantity. 

Part of the reason these items are so coveted is that supply is often fixed or severely constrained at any level of demand.

5/ Normal economic goods derive their price from their function. 

This causes the demand for a normal good to increase as its price decreases and vice versa.

Luxury goods have an opposite relationship. A luxury good‚Äôs price is what creates its psychological function. https://t.co/fwCPBeFYGR

4/ Luxury goods can be broken down into three distinct tiers: inaccessible, intermediate, & accessible. 

Inaccessible luxury goods are the most expensive or scarce & ultimately serve as the starting point for consumers to determine the value of the intermediate & accessible. https://t.co/xx9fvnko8d

3/ NFTs can function just like physical goods, satisfying both practical & psychological needs.

NFTs provide their owners with a sense of social belonging within online communities and satisfy esteem needs when owners display them as status symbols.

2/ Luxury goods can be better understood as a domain that exists across a variety of industries.

Unlike normal economic goods, Luxury goods are purchased mainly to satisfy their owners‚Äô psychological need for social belonging or self-esteem https://t.co/GXustZWXFh

1/ There‚Äôs an argument to be made that NFTs serve a psychological function for their owners that resembles the role of luxury goods. 

By exploring the characteristics of luxury goods, we can establish a new framework to better understand how value is created in the NFT market. https://t.co/BZSLqyfHcI

11/ Learn more about the State of @compoundfinance Q1 in the full Quarterly Report from @SeanButta. 

https://t.co/xrHtqWfV0V

10/ $COMP token incentives fell drastically by 52% in Q1. 

These incentives are a key driver of depositor and borrower activity. 

Governance passed a proposal at the end of Q1 that would reduce $COMP incentives by 50% with plans to eliminate incentive rewards. https://t.co/gJsSWMyibx

9/ Liquidations on @compoundfinance peaked towards the end of January, growing 295% quarter-over-quarter. 

This activity was largely due to liquidations across the $WETH and $USDC markets resulting in increases of 270% and 665%, respectively. https://t.co/nPWWKl6lUo

7/ The narrative continues across originations (new loans) for Q1. 

Total originations were down 53% in the quarter, led by $DAI with a $2.9 billion drop (66%), over the quarter. https://t.co/OPc5gaCnIh

6/ Interest income for the quarter deteriorated by 54% compared to Q4 2021. 

Coincidentally, interest and protocol income virtually experienced the same percentage changes in Q1. 

Quarterly interest income was impacted because market volatility decreased loan appetite. https://t.co/tr4VEIKhIY

5/ The average quarterly depositor interest rate was 1.51%, down from 2.04% in Q4. 

Annualized interest rates hit a low of 1.19% in Q1 and peaked at 1.87%. https://t.co/RQkyp5LxEa

4/ Outstanding deposits were down 32% in Q1 with the steepest decline transitioning into February. 

Similar to outstanding loan volumes, deposits approached TTM lows seen in Q2 2021. https://t.co/CiWrAJkJxp

3/ Borrower interest rates were relatively stable compared to the prior quarter. 

The average annualized interest rate was 3.85%, down from 5.02% in Q4. https://t.co/ew7fn3WSxX

2/ Outstanding loans were down 42% in the quarter, dropping to levels seen back in Q1 2021, when the total crypto market cap also had a cooling period. 

Loans in stablecoins denominated in USDC and DAI continued to outpace loans denominated in other assets. https://t.co/J8hsMhg7St

1/ As Q1 2022 wrapped up, many key performance indicators for @compoundfinance experienced substantial declines. 

The quarter ended with a 42% decline in outstanding loans, a 32% decline in outstanding deposits, a 53% decline in originations, & a 79% decline in deposits. https://t.co/aeXTIsCUks

7/ Learn more about the State of @avalancheavax Q1 in the full Quarterly Report from @JamesTrautman_. 

https://t.co/IacZqtG0tk

6/ As daily active addresses & transactions grew, total revenue increased. 

Revenue grew by 72.7% over the quarter, and cumulative revenue became a more significant fraction of the network Fully Diluted Valuation (FDV). https://t.co/tmYvbSvBby

5/ Further, the continued launch of subnets should put downward pressure on transaction fees. 

Subnets are a horizontal scaling strategy that aims to validate Avalanche blockchains running in parallel, enabling transaction order, and increased performance.

4/ Throughout 2021, the network experienced volatility in average daily transaction fees. 

With further releases of Apricot, transaction fees have since stabilized, averaging around $0.67 per transaction.

3/ Similar to Q4, transaction activity on the network followed a similar pattern to daily active address growth. 

On aggregate, @avalancheavax's average daily transactions rose from 473,000 last quarter to 865,000 in Q1, which is ~ 74% of Ethereum‚Äôs roughly 1.17 million. https://t.co/HqDej7seIh

2/ Daily active addresses did not reverse course, & instead, adoption continued as active addresses reached an all-time-high of 140,000 in January. 

For perspective, @avalancheavax had more active users in the first week of January than in all of October 2021. https://t.co/qjuDx7h5QJ

1/ @avalancheavax experienced modest growth compared to Q4 2021 & its key metrics stabilized across the network. 

While market cap was relatively flat, the network experienced continued uptrends in usage, revenue generation, & a move towards favorable fundamental valuation. üî∫ https://t.co/Dp1AxnYchZ

7/ The DAG-based blockchain technology is truly a unique approach to solving the blockchain trilemma. 

Learn more about @FantomFDN  in the full Enterprise article from @dunleavy89.

https://t.co/eTDk7TxwuC

6/ Overall the token accrues value through staking rewards and network fees. 

The more users transact & interact with ecosystem applications, the more value the token should accrue in the form of cash flow.

5/ @FantomFDN uses $FTM as its native token. FTM‚Äôs uses include as a governance token, network security mechanism via staking, & payment mechanism for transactions and fees. 

For network security, stakers are required to lock up 500,000 FTM & maintain industrial-grade hardware

4/ @FantomFDN's Ware layer provides open-source APIs and smart contract functionality. 

The main codebase is written in Solidity, and applications are EVM-compatible. Fantom is developing its own Fantom Virtual Machine (FVM) to replace the EVM in the Ware layer. https://t.co/9K2XHGu3pY

3/ The DAG structure is the underlying technology of a novel consensus mechanism called Lachesis. 

Lachesis is asynchronous, meaning nodes can independently reach consensus. 

They then periodically exchange transactions to agree on what has recently happened on the network.

2/ @FantomFDN attempts to solve the blockchain trilemma by utilizing a directed acyclic graph (DAG) structure for its nodes. 

This structure increases throughput because transactions don‚Äôt need to be serialized like they do in a traditional blockchain. https://t.co/d87X8e2YEy

1/ @FantomFDN is a Proof-of-Stake Layer-1 smart contract platform competing directly with @ethereum, @solana, @avalancheavax , & others. 

Fantom calls their ecosystem Opera. The Opera ecosystem is made up of two main layers: the Ware layer & the Consensus (core) layer. https://t.co/EZg42mcQVQ

https://t.co/BTFm7mUiAM

6/ The NFT gaming playbook has focused on selling NFTs and combining staking or yield farming to create financial incentives to ‚Äúplay‚Äù the game. 

There are no notable NFT games that concentrate on monetizing via social value. https://t.co/5EOCmxsFfE

4/ Today, most games monetize recurrent revenue on one of two axes: 

+Social: Selling in-game assets that showcase status or cosmetic value. 

+Utility: Assets with in-game value. https://t.co/klLRj6Iyxk

3/ Gaming mercenaries will move from one yield farming game to the next.

Often P2E yield farming activities are supported by ‚Äúscholarship programs.‚Äù 

Effectively, scholars perform repetitive in-game activities and split a portion of the profits with the NFT owners.

2/ The existing model has several severe flaws that prevent its long-term success:

+The ability to purchase NFTs or in-game currency effectively creating pay-to-win game mechanics.

+Significant upfront investment.

+Play-to-earn games not being fun-to-play.

1/ The gaming industry's most recent innovation wave has been the rise of GameFi ‚Äî the greater financialization of gaming assets. 

The first GameFi monetization model ‚Äî play-to-earn (P2E) ‚Äî was popularized by @AxieInfinity. https://t.co/Bq1UxnedKh

6/ While decentralized storage is still in its early days, the Filecoin ecosystem has been thriving over the years.

Learn more about @FilFoundation's @Filecoin in the full Hub article from @tech_metrics and @Old_Samster. 

https://t.co/fMUecnWf33

5/ @Filecoin has been able to attract significant storage capacity. 

Filecoin‚Äôs committed storage capacity has grown steadily to over 16,000 PiB, which is equivalent to approximately 65,000 copies of Wikipedia or 1,600 Netflix movie archives as of March 2022. https://t.co/CIH6PusESS

4/ @Filecoin is built on top of the Interplanetary File System (IPFS). 

IPFS essentially tells users where their data is, but it lacks a built-in mechanism to incentivize data storage, which led to the development of Filecoin in the first place.

3/ @Filecoin has two functions to keep data safe:

+Cryptoeconomic guarantee that verifies the storage with zero-knowledge proofs. 

+Economic penalty: if the data is unretrievable or the storage fails, storage providers are penalized through locked-up collateral.

2/ A storage deal is similar to a service level agreement (SLA) enforced on the @Filecoin blockchain. 

Storage deals are agreements where users pay fees to storage providers to store their data. 

To incentivize storage providers, Filecoin rewards them w/ native token $FIL.

1/ @Filecoin is a peer-to-peer version of AWS that regularly verifies data availability and integrity. 

This is made possible by deals negotiated on open markets for data services. https://t.co/vNVePC5LDw

4/ @MinaProtocol has been building a promising solution to capitalize on the potential in the zero-knowledge space without compromising on decentralization.

Learn more about @MinaProtocol in the full Pro article from @kunalgoel.

https://t.co/uuUAw5RKJj

3/ SNARKs are a type of zero-knowledge proof. They are called succinct because they are small and easy to verify. 

@MinaProtocol uses a type of zk-SNARK called Pickles that can recursively refer to itself, thus creating proofs of proofs and keeping the blockchain a fixed size. https://t.co/zKzOrpoEyi

2/ @MinaProtocol uses cryptography called recursive zk-SNARKs, which stands for zero-knowledge succinct non-interactive argument of knowledge.

Zero-knowledge proofs are a way to prove something with the verifier learning no information other than the statement is true.

1/ @MinaProtocol uses recursive cryptography to keep a verifiable version of the blockchain restricted to a fixed size of about 11kB.

Mina is able to stay a fixed size by using a self-referencing series of cryptographic proofs. https://t.co/l54W2331jd

8/ @AlchemixFi V1 was the minimum viable product used to test the feasibility of CDPs built on top of yield-generating strategies.

Alchemix V2 has been designed with an emphasis on both flexibility and composability.

7/ @AlchemixFi CDPs don‚Äôt carry liquidation risk. 

This has prompted a few users to use the protocol to finance real-world purchases such as an engagement ring and a boat.

6/ Arbitrageurs can buy the asset while simultaneously shorting a futures contract against its price to collect an interest premium from the buyer of the futures contract. 

The arbitrageur could run this strategy while collecting interest in two places at once using @AlchemixFi.

5/ @AlchemixFi V2‚Äôs composable properties should allow protocols to use Alchemix Vaults as tools. 

The algorithmic stablecoin protocol @SperaxUSD deposits its collateral assets into interest protocols & passes the interest revenue back to its holders.

4/ Those that choose to open @AlchemixFi Vaults with their treasuries would be able to lower their costs on a real and nominal basis. 

With the delegated credit feature, DAOs could pay contributors or fund grants directly from their own yield.

3/ Using @AlchemixFi, the conservative crypto user looking to experiment with DeFi could lower their exposure to smart contract risk in three simple steps: 

1. Deposit base assets into Alchemix, 
2. Max borrow alAssets
3. Swap alAssets back to base assets on Curve or Saddle.

2/ Users deposit assets into @AlchemixFi which then deploys the funds to other protocols.

Users gain access to a synthetic line of credit against their deposited liquidity. 

Any yield generated on a user‚Äôs collateral is used to automatically pay down their credit line. https://t.co/pP8zoHy3oi

The framework focuses primarily on the depth and concentration of liquidity for the asset/$WETH pair on Uniswap V3. https://t.co/wYjodofdBa

3/ @eulerfinance implements both collateral and borrow factors.

With both collateral and borrow factors, Euler is able to account upfront for price action in either direction for borrowed assets. https://t.co/NuEYNjqeAj

2/ Euler allows anyone to create a lending market for an asset as long as it has a $WETH pair on Uniswap V3.

Utilizing TWAPs for asset pricing implies that @eulerfinance markets will be less responsive to and impacted by volatile price movements in the wider market. https://t.co/GbGRHP2OAE

1/ The @eulerfinance lending and borrowing protocol recently deployed in December 2021 to the @ethereum mainnet and has attracted ~$85 million in deposits, with $USDC accounting for ~75% of total deposits.

4/ @NEARProtocol partnered w/ the @oct_network to allow developers to build & launch their own ‚Äúapp chains‚Äù, which are designed for specific use cases & work in parallel with the main chain. 

@oct_network provides prebuilt app chains with functionality for developers. https://t.co/qbbanzXrMK

3/ @NEARProtocol's blockchain can be used to run smart contracts, but it also has compatibility with the @ethereum Virtual Machine.

It has deployed a smart contract on the main network, called Aurora, essentially acting as its own stand-alone network, but as a smart contract. https://t.co/prfDUz1psi

2/ @NEARProtocol's block production technique is called ‚ÄúDoomSlug‚Äù. 

DoomSlug allows NEAR to achieve so-called ‚Äúpractical finality‚Äù for transactions after just one round of communication across validators instead of waiting for multiple blocks like @ethereum.

1/ @NEARProtocol uses a type of proof-of-stake (PoS) consensus algorithm known as Thresholded Proof-of-Stake.

5/ @terra_money's Columbus-5 Upgrade has propelled $UST to the largest decentralized stablecoin and has created immense value for $LUNA holders.

Learn more about @terra_money in this Hub article from @WillComyns. 

https://t.co/6anb7l8aj9

4/ While $DAI is technically a decentralized stablecoin, it is primarily collateralized by $USDC, making it quite centralized relative to $UST. 

$USTs supply is now 17% larger than $DAI as it continues to grow at a rate faster than its more centralized peers. https://t.co/wAuTiADO2A

3/ Before 100% of seigniorage was burned, a portion was allocated to validators to encourage accurate voting.

To compensate, Columbus-5 dividends swap fees to validators that would have otherwise been burned.

This change has resulted in higher yields & more $LUNA staked. https://t.co/7jPDMAacJb

2/ Seigniorage occurs when $LUNA is exchanged to mint new $UST. 

Prior to TIP43 and Columbus-5, whenever $UST was minted, the @terra_money protocol would burn a portion of earned $LUNA, & the rest would be diverted to fund various community projects.

1/ @terra_money's Columbus-5 upgrade is mainly responsible for $USTs recent supply growth. 

Columbus-5 was initiated with the primary goal of simplifying the economic design of @terra_money & improving the value capture of $LUNA holders based on $USTs growth.

5/ The shift towards new immersive technologies will require new web infrastructure in order to scale. 

Learn more about @RenderToken in this Pro article from @Old_Samster. https://t.co/5dbwEpFc4Z

4/ @RenderToken Network relies on a governance system called Proof-of-Render (PoR), which resembles the popular Proof-of-Work (PoW) consensus. 

PoR builds a reputation score for network users and node operators in order to build a peer-to-peer network of trusted nodes.

3/ @RenderToken Network makes it possible to have millions of GPUs running on the public cloud with no marginal capital expenditure.

If 1% of the available GPUs in circulation were to plug into the Render Network, there would be a 5300% increase in capacity to the public cloud.

2/ The current GPU infrastructure available is not scalable enough to provide the computing capability required for the shift to more immersive virtual experiences. 

The number of GPUs in the public cloud was a fraction of the amount of GPUs in circulation. https://t.co/sthZqjdGLU

1/ The @RenderToken Network is a peer-to-peer distributed GPU computing platform that democratizes computing and rendering power. 

Render Network allows for unlimited scaling across parallel GPU nodes, enabling high speed and efficient rendering with end-to-end encryption. https://t.co/Rp7JZUiP1s

4/ Parcels in @TheSandboxGame are separated into 1x1, 3x3, 6x6, 12x12, and 24x24 parcel plots.

This effectively helps determine which plots of LAND are most desirable. https://t.co/dDWtMgtPyC

3/ The median price of @TheSandboxGame LAND has appreciated from $1,308 at the end of Q3 to a median price of $11,364 by the end of Q4.

2/ LANDS are blockchain-backed tokens (using the ERC-721 standard for non-fungible tokens, aka NFTs) representing physical parcels of The Sandbox Metaverse. 

There is a finite amount of @TheSandboxGame LAND ‚Äì 166,464 parcels of which 62% have already been distributed. https://t.co/YC3zubKveA

1/ The @TheSandboxGame is a gaming metaverse ‚Äì virtual world ‚Äì where players and creators can make 3D assets and experiences (e.g. games) that can be monetized via NFTs.

4/ Finally, ownership of NFTs unlock another crucial tool in the Web3 arsenal: incentive alignment through tokenization.

For example, @AudiusProject plans to subvert the dominant music streaming platforms by rewarding artists and their users directly via its $AUDIO token. https://t.co/eNJa6GPDHS

3/ @AsyncArt is another example.

Whereas most platforms will tokenize your entire piece of work, Async enables the fractionalization of your creation into subcomponents.

Imagine a popular DJ releasing a master of their music with underlying layers ownable and editable by fans. https://t.co/ED6LZ8cUKM

2/ @join_royal is a platform that empowers fans to earn royalties alongside their favorite artists.

Artists retain the ownership and independence that would have previously been controlled by middlemen, but can also dictate future revenue streams, exclusive fan benefits, etc.

1/ According to a @Citi report, artists generally only capture 12% of the revenue from their music.

The infographic below is a breakdown of revenue in the music industry. Note the distribution allocated to parties such as platform cost and record labels.

Crypto & NFTs fix this. https://t.co/Ii35wbQLIK

3/ What differentiates PoX from PoS?

Miners and stackers are not the same entity whereas in PoS they can coincide.
