2/ Instead of deploying smart contracts directly on the Bitcoin chain, @Stacks executes them on its own L1 blockchain and uses BTC for settlement only.

It communicates with the Bitcoin blockchain through a novel consensus mechanism called Proof of Transfer (PoX).

1/ There are 2 fundamental challenges to building apps and smart contracts on Bitcoin:

+ Bitcoin blockchain has a limited capacity for transactions.
+ Smart contract scripting language is quite limited.

@Stacks has developed a solution for both issues. https://t.co/bP2BIoEnF4

4/ Until a clear competitor for the EVM emerges, it seems likely that the pattern will continue: a consolidated set of dapps deployed across all EVM chains, against a siloed non-EVM space with each platform nursing its own menagerie of dapps.

3/ It is very unlikely that dapp developers, most of whom form small teams, will be able to target a long list of virtual machine types.

They are more likely to target number one and two in the market, and add integrations to smaller chains on a low-priority basis.

2/ Because developers care, and developers are the key to success.

If you're building a platform, your primary users are developers - they create the attractions that bring in users.

This makes platform choice a critical variable for developers to decide upon from the outset.

1/ As the name suggests, liquid staking is the process through which a user can gain liquidity on their staked assets.

4/ Learn more about the @helium Network AKA "The People's Network" in the full article from @Old_Samster https://t.co/GiZDlEJQK7

3/ As of January 2021, roughly 136,860 hotspots are online, representing 90% of the network.

There are currently @helium hotspots deployed in 119 countries.

Although the US has the most hotspots (~54% of the total), there are hotspots all over North America, Europe, and Asia. https://t.co/09wAriuUp5

2/ Hotspots provide wireless coverage, but also act as a network node and a miner for $HNT.

Customers transfer data using Data Credit (DC), which is set at a fixed price of $0.0001/byte.

When DC is acquired, HNT is burned, reducing the HNT in circulation & increasing the value. https://t.co/qtT0oyJqF6

1/ @helium is a decentralized telecommunications network that uses LoRaWAN technology to connect Internet of Things (IoT) devices to the internet.

AKA The People‚Äôs Network, Helium has reached a tremendous milestone of over 150,000 hotspots deployed globally in just over 2 years.

4/ Learn more about the decentralization of identity in the latest article from @karimhal22 https://t.co/AmTN5MV97M

3/ 1B people worldwide are unable to claim ownership over their identity, rendering them unable to own property, vote, find legal employment, etc.

DIDs empower those without legal identification to seize control over their identity and represent themselves in a verifiable way. https://t.co/JmNuHbQ9fz

2/ An on-chain identity is the attachment of a blockchain public key to a real-world identity.

This can belong to a person, or something more abstract, like a data model.

This is called a Decentralized Identity (DID) - the owner has full sovereignty and controls how it is used.

1/ The issue with our digital identities and accompanying data is that it is collated: lumped together to create a digital representation of ourselves. 

And there is little transparency over how they are managed by the intermediaries which are trusted to manage them.

4/ Learn more about exclusivity and the paradox it creates in the latest article from @masonnystrom https://t.co/JcjgxG1hey

3/ Exclusive platforms work differently.

When growing an exclusive community, later members typically see diminishing returns.

Financially-derived exclusivity/membership is a double edge sword ‚Äì it builds a strong community, but naturally limits the community's size & growth.

2/ This paradox does not occur with non-membership-based tokens.

For example, each new buyer of #Bitcoin adds value ‚Äì increasing the scarcity ‚Äì of Bitcoin and therefore all members are aligned.

New nodes or members to the network increase the value of the network.

1/ The ‚ÄúSocial Token Paradox‚Äù is a problem that occurs in exclusive social tokens communities.

The challenge is that social tokens need new members for the value to appreciate, yet these membership-gated communities must also maintain exclusivity to keep their value. https://t.co/TM8nwCmByk

5/ Learn more about @MetisDAO in the full article from @r_sale https://t.co/iDeJ8LYxlk

4/ Like other optimistic rollup designs, @MetisDAO uses on sequencers to order/batch transactions before submitting the final MVM state changes to Ethereum.

Unlike the others, Metis intends to pool the sequencers into on-chain entities called Decentralized Autonomous Companies. https://t.co/vIzA41FvlI

3/ @MetisDAO will be one of the family of EVM-compatible optimistic rollups to launch within the coming months.

It uses a fork of Optimism‚Äôs Optimism Virtual Machine (OVM) that it calls the Metis Virtual Machine (MVM).

The MVM mirrors the OVM in function and code execution.

2/ There are 2 forms of rollups: ZK & optimistic rollups.

@MetisDAO uses the latter.

Optimistic rollups assume ‚Äúoptimistically‚Äù that all transactions are valid.

But transaction confirmations on the main chain are subject to a challenge period as a fraud prevention mechanism.

1/ @MetisDAO seeks to offer the standard benefits of optimistic rollups:

+ low fees (<$1)
+ speed (<1s)
+ ETH-level economic security

It plans to stand out by providing native data storage, faster withdrawals to the ETH L1 main chain, and improved usability for DApp providers. https://t.co/pNx0BmKSdd

4/ Get the full breakdown of @kp3r_network on the latest article from @jerrysun_  https://t.co/pjEQYZwmqo

3/ In V1, rewards for performing jobs are paid in either $ETH or $KP3R.

Keepers are incentivized to ‚Äústake‚Äù their KP3R on the network in a process called bonding. Bonded tokens are not tradeable, but help build "reputation", enabling keepers to qualify for higher level jobs. https://t.co/uSMnn1u0f8

2/ On the Keep3r Network, protocols post jobs along with any relevant materials needed to perform the task. 

Keepers can register for jobs, complete them, and subsequently collect a reward for their work. 

Since activity is on-chain, finished jobs can be easily verified. https://t.co/VuCjfZZWPo

1/ Blockchain-based dapps are no different than other software apps, and require a DevOps tool of sorts.

Ethereum L2s/sidechains/L1 competitors are ushering in a wave of perpetual trading on decentralized platforms. Top protocols include: 

+ @perpprotocol accounts for 80%+ of the decentralized futures trading vol
+ @dydxprotocol is the 2nd largest
+ @futureswapx 
+ @MonteCarloDEX https://t.co/UujW1PBRDA

The key dynamics influencing the market adoption of decentralized futures markets are:

+ faster/cheaper transactions
+ liquidity composability
+ depth of markets 

So who are the top protocols seeking to solve these issues for DeFi?

Spot leading in DeFi makes sense for 3 reasons:

+ DeFi grew on Ethereum where slow settlements/high costs make decentralized futures markets unfeasible
+ Physical tokens have utility/value in DeFi compared to being stored on a CEX
+ Decentralized platforms lack market depth/size

The largest business in DeFi today is DEXs. Specifically, spot trading. However, spot exchanges on CEXs are 10-20% smaller than the largest business: futures trading.

CEXs do over 110% of the spot vols in futures markets while decentralized counterparts do just 6%‚Ää. What gives?

To learn more about governance tokens and the latent power that they hold, read the full article by @masonnystrom https://t.co/Vkl4d7phc9

Governance tokens also can be used to set parameters for:
+ inflation
+ token distribution
+ liquidity mining rewards

Parameters aren‚Äôt always governed on-chain and sometimes require social consensus, however, many networks can be altered by token holders.

As a service:

Protocols that primarily use governance tokens for key decision making naturally accrue greater governance power.

Governance-heavy protocols like @NexusMutual allow stakers to make key decisions through the use of tokens. To hold more tokens is to hold more power. https://t.co/gLvRgcVaNx

There's no such thing as a valueless governance token, only one whose value is yet to be utilized.

Governance tokens can be activated
+ as a function/service required within the protocol 
+ to control assets of a protocol
+ to alter the existing parameters of a given network https://t.co/S1Frqf3SZH

In the near future, the protocol plans to:
 
+ Take in new reserve assets
+ Introduce locked staking to incentivize long-term stakers
+ Build partnerships with other DeFi protocols

The protocol stabilizes via algorithmic market ops.

If 1 OHM > 1 DAI, the protocol sells OHM at a discount, increasing circulating supply and bringing price down (and vice versa).

The protocol always sells at a higher price than it buys, so it always makes a profit. https://t.co/70kyHtZZbo

.@OlympusDAO's vision is for its token $OHM to become a stable free floating currency backed by reserve assets and used as the base currency of the crypto economy. 

Like a private bank, it mints its own banknotes (OHM) which are always fully backed by the assets in the treasury.

IPY = (current borrow rate) x (total outstanding debt)

The data shows that IPY is a good indicator of price recovery but not a good indicator of price change. This means that, in a dip, investors could confidently allocate capital to protocols that have maintained IPY. https://t.co/cU9rNsCsre

We hypothesize fundamentals matter & value must accrue to protocol/investors. We use various weekly data metrics to find daily outliers

+ # of active users
+ Trading vols on DEXs
+ TVL
+ IPY on lending protocols
+ Amount deposited in lending protocols/amount of outstanding loans

To learn more about miner extractable value (MEV), read the full article from Tesa Ho https://t.co/GWuLV2FZZn

There are many private networks that connect miners with MEV bots. These networks include

+ Flashbots
+ @Keeper_DAO 
+ @bloXrouteLabs' backrunme
+ @Archer_DAO  
+ Alchemist‚Äôs https://t.co/D0iL7sarC4

As the amount of realized MEV has grown, MEV bot operators have begun sending their transactions through private networks like Flashbots. 

These private networks allow operators to send transactions directly to miners and share the proceeds in exchange for transaction execution. https://t.co/iu2rvCGkFk

Before an Ethereum transaction is included in a block, it goes to the Mempool, a publicly accessible staging area.

There MEV bots search for transactions that they can use to capture MEV through arbitraging markets or liquidating newly undercollateralized loans.

MEV (recently redefined as maximal extractible value) is the additional profit miners can make by altering transactions within blocks they produce. 

Winning a block is fairly democratic, but the winning producer has significant control over the transactions that can be included. https://t.co/q4Q349WNIK

$OXT is an ERC-20 token that powers Orchid. It has two functions:

+ Payment for bandwidth: a liquid token to facilitate usage
+ Staking: as collateral by providers and to increase expected revenues

@OrchidProtocol is an open market, so providers set their own prices and clients set how much they are willing to pay for the service.

Currently, only providers with enterprise level bandwidth and resources are allowed to be sellers. They plan to expand to individuals soon.

The nodes are chosen by using a stake-weighted linear selection process. Users may also add their own node filters, such as latency, geolocation, or custom metadata tags.

In exchange for this service, clients pay nodes with probabilistic nanopayments in a pay as you go fashion. https://t.co/3KLH7wuBxR

@OrchidProtocol is a decentralized VPN market that allows users to route traffic through various nodes randomly reordered at each step. 

Unlike other dVPNs, Orchid adds extra security by adding another layer of encryption each time the connection is routed through another node. https://t.co/tnPGyRbiB0

To learn more about The Graph and accessing on-chain data, read the full article from @thecryptogus https://t.co/XencMEAUo4

@graphprotocol offers querying services for both L1/L2 solutions, such as

+ @ethereum
+ @0xPolygon
+ @avalancheavax
+ @BinanceChain

They have plans to integrate @Polkadot, @solana, and @NEARProtocol. They will eventually enable support for all major L1 chains, incl. Bitcoin.

@graphprotocol's native token, GRT, is an ERC-20 token built on Ethereum. 

Consumers spend GRT to submit query requests, and indexers, curators, and delegators are compensated for their services in GRT. https://t.co/h1NTvGm4BN

@graphprotocol has several stakeholders 

+ Developers: define subgraphs
+ Indexers: maintain the protocol
+ Curators: signal which subgraphs are best
+ Delegators: delegate their tokens to indexers and share indexing reward
+ End Users: submit queries, pay with GRT https://t.co/Dg6Qfv4n0P

Some advantages of @graphprotocol:

+ Dapps don't have to maintain their APIs themselves
+ Protocol data is decentralized
+ It allows developers to have a common query structure and language for all protocols of any open blockchain

To learn more the future of intangible assets, read @masonnystrom's latest article https://t.co/a3LI1G7bky

We can expect to see this shift over time as more niche marketplaces arise for specific types of intangible assets. 

Ultimately, intangible assets are going on-chain and in the process unlocking billions of dollars in value.

The popularity of digital property (NFTs) has been made possible through this transition. 

Open NFT marketplaces like @OpenSea/@rariblecom are early venues for purchasing liquid intellectual property like EulerBeats representing items that carry social status in digital worlds.

The shift from valuing intangible assets evolved with the advent of the internet and the U.S transition to a service-based economy.  

~90% of the market value of the S&P 500 comes from intangible assets (i.e. intellectual property, brands) versus tangible assets. https://t.co/YR9WemEjJ7

Today, NFTs provide an opportunity to turn intangible assets into programmable assets on permissionless blockchains. However, before the 90's the most valuable assets were tangible assets. 

The top assets?

+ Manufacturing
+ Equipment
+ Real Estate https://t.co/L1444yooMN

Learn more about the Lightning Network and everything it has to offer in @GuerillaV2's latest article https://t.co/2hxTV3IwkG

There have been major transactional improvements over the years including

+ Wumbo channels allow large routing nodes to support higher daily vols
+ Multi Path Payments significantly reduce fragmentation of the network liquidity
+ And more https://t.co/FYTt7Fp5nB

If we expect the LN to become the de facto solution to scale Bitcoin transactions in the near future, is the network ready? 

With $65M in TVL, LN pales in comparison to DeFi. https://t.co/c3L2zNmeaw

Micropayments are the original vision for the Lightning Network. However, the LN ecosystem is very diverse and the system has a variety of uses such as

+ Private messaging
+ Podcast monetization
+ Gaming

The Lightning Network (LN) is the largest deployed Layer 2 payment channel network. 

A payment channel network consists of a series of individual payment channels, which, when strung together, enable rapid low-latency payments between participants in the network.

As Bitcoin becomes increasingly popular, it is clear that people will look for ways to make cheaper on-chain transactions. 

@lightning has been one of the solutions long proposed by Bitcoiners in order to solve Bitcoin‚Äôs scalability problems. https://t.co/3q2GhM1y7h

To learn more about @compoundfinance's Gateway blockchain, read @WillComyns's latest article https://t.co/6t9sQvBU64

A major goal of Gateway is to get blockchains to interact directly without token wrapping.

To wrap tokens, users go through 3rd party intermediaries and in doing so lose control of their private keys.

Gateway allows Bitcoin users to interact with other chains w/o 3rd parties. https://t.co/oI93WwVNJ1

Gateway is a stand-alone blockchain built around cross-chain interoperability. It allows

+ users to upload assets from a variety of blockchains through its system of peer chains
+ enable the starport contract to lock/unlock assets
+ users to lend/borrow assets b/t blockchains https://t.co/twezgKGkIa

@compoundfinance, a leading money market protocol,  released the whitepaper for Gateway in December. Gateway allows for: 

+ The ability to borrow and lend any asset from any blockchain
+ Interest to be earned/paid in dollars (stablecoins), using CASH
+ A more robust risk engine

By having specific lending pairs where the collateral can only be used to borrow one specific asset (eg. in a ETH/SUSHI pair, deposited ETH acts as the collateral for SUSHI and only SUSHI), the risk for users can be isolated to the quality of assets and oracle used for the pair.

Kashi Lending is the first DApp built on top of BentoBox. It is both a lending and margin trading platform. Kashi is powered by isolated lending pairs, which are similar to liquidity pools but with one side used purely as collateral for the other side, which is lent out.

Advantages: 

+ storing assets in one central underlying vault enables more efficient token transfers

+ lower transaction complexity and gas fees 

+ a single token approval for use within BentoBox 

+ developers can more easily tap into Sushiswap's existing user base
BentoBox is a single vault that holds all of the assets deposited by users and makes them accessible to be utilized by any DApp built off of the vault.

SushiSwap is currently responsible for just under 15% of all DEX volume. 

Their two latest features were released as part of an aggressive strategy to expand beyond simply being a DEX.

How $BNT/vBNT staking works:

Users supply tokens to liquidity pools for automated trading. $BNT stakers receive $BNT trading fees (and re-stake them for vBNT and 1x leverage) but all users get full coverage against Impermanent Loss after 30 days of staking.

How the Bancor DEX works:

Bancor integrates a series of smart contracts to exchange Ethereum and EOS tokens in liquidity pools. $BNT is minted and connected to each token at a constant ratio so prices reflect supply & demand.

Token Type: ERC-20

Bancor was the first automated market maker (AMM) DEX on Ethereum. The protocol matches $BNT with all pooled tokens to create trading pairs. Users can stake $BNT or any token without unintended asset exposure. https://t.co/pgtYzOpibn

Consensus & Emission:

$BNT supply is elastic with Bancor V2.1. The protocol matches liquidity pool token deposits with minted $BNT and burns $BNT when tokens are withdrawn. Users‚Äô $BNT deposits replace minted $BNT to control inflation. https://t.co/Xh0ZACIHV4

@Barn_Bridge is a risk tokenizing protocol.

It allows hedging yield sensitivity and price volatility by accessing debt pools on other DeFi protocols and transforming single pools into multiple assets with varying risk/return characteristics.

@saffronfinance_ is a peer-to-peer risk exchange protocol.

The protocol allows its users (i.e. liquidity providers) to customize their risk and return profiles via the use of SFI pool tranches.

They are doing so through securitization and risk-tranching.

Securitization is the merging or pooling of financial assets into interest-bearing securities.

Tranching is the slicing up of those securities into buckets to be sold according to their unique risks, maturities etc.

Poor risk management solutions are pain points in DeFi expansion. Two newer players are looking to provide de-risking for the next gen of users:

+ @saffronfinance_ 
+ @barn_bridge https://t.co/QJDYqkU6vr

Although data points are limited at this time, RAI has been remarkably stable following its volatile start as market participants get more familiar with RAI‚Äôs mechanics and arbitrage RAI around its redemption price. https://t.co/zSlKxvMzA0

‚ÄúIt works kind of like a spring: the further the market price of RAI moves from the target price, the more powerful the interest rate, and the greater the incentive to return RAI to equilibrium.‚Äù - @ameensol https://t.co/GuOWbmyqXz
Essentially the system devalues or revalues RAI according to a redemption rate (rate at which RAI is being devalued or revalued) to incentivize people to borrow or pay back their debt.
The way this works is that as RAI moves away from its redemption price, the protocol automatically adjusts its redemption price to proportionally oppose the price move in order to stabilize RAI.

However, RAI introduces a number of changes to the SCD model.

First and foremost, RAI is not pegged to the dollar and instead pegged to itself.

It starts out with an arbitrary target price (called the redemption price) that it adjusts to influence the market price of RAI.

Users can open this position by depositing ETH into a SAFE (similar to Maker‚Äôs vaults) and minting RAI against it.

Users can redeem their collateral by paying back their RAI plus a borrow fee.

RAI‚Äôs token FLX is used to govern and backstop the system. https://t.co/ZOGcBr6Aut

At a high level RAI is similar to Single Collateral DAI (SCD).

It is an overcollateralized debt position for users that demand ETH leverage.

RAI is a governance minimized non pegged stablecoin.

It is an attempt to create a more trust-minimized version Dai not pegged to the dollar.

It is solely backed by ETH and stabilized autonomously using a PID controller.

For more on Float Protocol check out our latest report on non pegged stablecoins. https://t.co/Mjbqvs5r8s

If FLOAT‚Äôs price is less than its Target Price, the protocol contracts the FLOAT supply through a reverse dutch auction.

The protocol offers to buy FLOAT in exchange for a mix of ETH and newly minted BANK. https://t.co/dHlkLIF0rC

If FLOAT‚Äôs price is greater than its Target Price, the protocol expands the FLOAT supply through a dutch auction.

The protocol sells newly minted FLOAT to arbitrageurs in exchange for a mix of ETH and BANK.

The ETH is put into the Basket while the BANK received is burned. https://t.co/e8PQ6EACuM

The Basket is owned by the protocol and is built up through FLOAT auctions.

FLOAT‚Äôs Target Price will start at an arbitrary number - initially $1.618 and will slowly adjust over time depending on the value of the basket relative to the value of the outstanding FLOAT. https://t.co/0nwCw38GK2

At the core of Float‚Äôs stability model is protocol controlled value (PCV) and dutch auctions.

Float protocol maintains a fund to stabilize the price of FLOAT called the ‚ÄúBasket‚Äù which holds a portfolio of cryptoassets - initially just ETH.

Float Protocol is a two token, partially collateralized non pegged stablecoin protocol.

FLOAT draws its value from its underlying basket of collateral (ETH), and is stabilized through auctions.

BANK backstops FLOAT, earns protocol profits, and governs the Float protocol.

Essentially a Bond provides a user the option to trade their OHM/DAI LP share with the protocol for OHM at a discount at a later date.

The purpose of this operation is to both incentivize and lock liquidity by offering yield. https://t.co/W55c1iLggb

Olympus DAO also features Bonds which are a secondary policy tool.

It enables Olympus DAO to both incentivize and accumulate OHM liquidity pool shares (this value also accrues to OHM stakers).

In each case the protocol makes a profit.

Olympus DAO distributes these profits 90% to OHM stakers pro rata and 10% to a DAO.

When OHM trades above 1 DAI, the protocol mints and sells new OHM.

When OHM trades below 1 DAI, the protocol buys back and burns OHM. https://t.co/Bt9WPVuUYd

Olympus DAO maintains a treasury (PCV) that ultimately provides a price floor on OHM.

It is built up through sales of OHM and through yield generating opportunities using its existing treasury assets (e.g depositing its treasury DAI into Compound to generate yield).
The core building blocks of Olympus DAO are protocol controlled value (PCV), market operations, and bonding.

At a high level Olympus DAO features a single token, OHM, which is both the system‚Äôs stable asset and its governance token.

OHM can be staked in return for sOHM which allows OHM holders to accrue protocol profits as well as participate in Olympus DAO governance. https://t.co/m0YJsPIieB

Olympus DAO is an attempt to create a stable currency (OHM) through managing a treasury of assets.

Initially this treasury will consist solely of DAI and OHM-DAI Sushi LP shares.

Over time Olympus DAO will add new collateral types and ultimately stabilize versus a basket.

Non pegged stablecoins ultimately derive their value from their underlying collateral (primarily ETH), similar to how the dollar did under the gold standard. https://t.co/HWJOx0WO7D

To address this stability issue, an independent Ethereum monetary system could issue currency against ETH and stabilize it algorithmically through incentives.

This is the core idea of the new wave of non pegged stablecoins: 

+ @reflexerfinance 
+ @FloatProtocol 
+ @OlympusDAO

It's volatile and undesirable to use for many financial activities that benefit from price stability. 

In other words, ETH may be a solid store of value, but it's a poor medium of exchange and unit of account.

ETH is decent money and will become better with time. It‚Äôs: 

+ scarce 
+ easy to verify 
+ fungible 
+ divisible 
+ portable 

With Ethereum 2.0 and EIP-1559, it's potentially deflationary. 

However, it‚Äôs not a great currency.

How does an independent Ethereum monetary system powered by non pegged stablecoins work in practice?

A liquidity provider migration portal will be available at launch, allowing v2 LPs to transfer their liquidity to the new protocol version without exiting their positions.
The Uniswap v3 smart contracts will be deployed to the Ropsten, Rinkeby, Kovan, and Gorli testnets in the coming days.

Liquidity positions will no longer be fungible and not represented as ERC20 tokens in v3. 

Uniswap v3 also includes updates to the TWAP oracle, making it possible to calculate any recent TWAP within the past ~9 days in a single on-chain call.
These features will allow for the introduction of a new function to complement market orders known as range orders.

One of the highlighted features of v3 include Concentrated Liquidity. 

This will allow LPs granular control over what price ranges their capital is allocated to and multiple fee tiers, allowing LPs to be compensated accordingly to the degrees of risk taken on in a position.

The @Uniswap team has released an overview of Uniswap v3. 

The team is targeting an L1 Ethereum mainnet launch on May 5, 2021, with an L2 deployment on Optimism shortly after.

5) @BitwiseInvest DeFi Crypto Index Fund 

The Bitwise DeFi Crypto Index is designed to expose accredited investors to DeFi. The fund is rebalanced monthly and aims to provide a market-cap weighted exposure to the largest DeFi protocols.

4) @defipulse Index (DPI)

A crypto-native index focused on providing investors with direct exposure to DeFi. The fund is a market capitalization-weighted index built on @SetProtocol's v2 infrastructure and consists of ten of the most popular tokens available on Ethereum.
The fund is administered by @business and co-branded with @GalaxyDigital Capital Management.

3) Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index

Measures e the performance of the largest cryptocurrencies in USD terms. The index is constructed based on market capitalization, subject to a weighting constraint specifying that no cryptocurrency should constitute more than 40% of the index.

2) @Grayscale Large Cap Fund

Market-cap weighted index that provides exposure to the upper 70% of the market. The fund rebalances on a quarterly basis and aims to maintain a market capitalization-weighted portfolio of Bitcoin, Ethereum, Bitcoin Cash, and Litecoin.

1) @BitwiseInvest 10 Crypto Index Fund

Seeks to track the performance of the 10 most valuable cryptocurrencies with the intention of providing exposure to approximately 80% of the market. The fund is rebalanced on a monthly basis and is weighted by market capitalization.

It intends to enhance smart contract programming by allowing developers to code with more commonly used software stacks and run them on a Linux OS.

Intensive and complex computations are handled off-chain, while Cartesi's rollup solution leverages underlying blockchain components for security and finalizing transactions. Cartesi also supports a Linux runtime environment for writing smart contracts.

The first is Descartes Rollups, which is a variant of an optimistic rollup. The second is Noether, a sidechain that provides data availability to applications. When combined, these products help Cartesi-based apps scale through both on-chain and off-chain components.

Cartesi is a Layer-2 platform for the development of smart contracts and decentralized applications (dApps). It intends to solve the problem of scalability and high fees on blockchains through two pieces of infrastructure.

In a market where information asymmetries run rampant, Messari Enterprise gives you a clear edge.¬†

A reason why all the top funds in crypto have signed up in droves.

Messari Enterprise users who opted to receive alerts about Aragon were pushed the notification and were able to act quickly (and we know from speaking to them, many of them did). https://t.co/TRKHPSa77Y
However, Messari analysts were on top of the vote and sent an alert right after the vote concluded. https://t.co/ZXGe7ZgX2O

You would think that information would be immediately priced in following the results of the vote.

But due to structural inefficiencies in crypto information channels, that's not what happened.

At the then ANT price of ~$3, that meant each ANJ ($0.04) could be redeemed for ~$0.13 of ANT. 

A clear trading opportunity.

The initial vote of 0.015 ANT was rejected and the winning proposal dictated that 1 ANJ could be redeemed for 0.044 ANT. 

3X HIGHER than what was originally proposed.

The problem was however, for any investor/trader with a vested interest in the event, there were NINE different on-chain votes to monitor at that time. The final result of this proposal was very difficult to keep up with.

In November, @AragonProject was in the process of deprecating the Aragon Court (ANJ) token by allowing holders to swap it for Aragon's native ANT token.

Initially, it was proposed to swap Aragon Court (ANJ) tokens with ANT at a ratio of 1 to 0.015.
In short, because Messari Enterprise quickly pays for itself by surfacing event driven trading opportunities. https://t.co/LsOqcv9llL

Learn all about SKALE‚Äôs history, roadmap, team, coin, launch, technology, security, and governance on their Messari asset profile. https://t.co/hgShyudIpG
In combination with Ethereum, SKALE Network aims to allow Web3 apps to compete with traditional apps on a cost and performance basis.

According to core developer SKALE Labs, SKALE chains can run full-state smart contracts, support decentralized storage, execute rollup contracts (a layer-2 scaling solution), and run machine learning algorithms using the EVM (Ethereum Virtual Machine).
Developers can rent SKALE chains that each act as a private Ethereum-compatible smart contract platform with faster block times and the ability to process up to 2,000 transactions per second.

SKALE Network is an open-source, decentralized "elastic" blockchain network designed to scale Web3 applications. SKALE chains are configurable, application-specific blockchains (often called "dynamic shards") that exist one layer above the Ethereum blockchain.

On Arbitrage & Delta Neutral Trading

This business is super enticing to delta neutral traders who hate risk and love perfectly hedging every aspect of their life.

Basis trading:  

Basis trading captures the difference between the futures price and cash price of an asset, you can do this with perp too making a bet of future financing via funding but either way this business is big and crypto generally trades contango so draws cash borrow
for borrow out of more traditional lenders.

You can also learn more about Secret Network here https://t.co/IESyBDz7au
Secret's data privacy technologies enable new types of dApps across multiple fields, including decentralized finance, access control, NFTs, gaming, data sharing, and more.

Secret Tokens (programmable like ERC-20s, but private by design like Monero) can be issued on Secret Network. Secret Bridges (such as the Secret Ethereum Bridge) create interoperability with other public blockchain ecosystems.
Secret is built on Tendermint SDK and uses Delegated Proof of Stake consensus. Secret Network's native coin, $SCRT, is used for transactional / computational fees, staking, and on-chain governance.

Secret Network is a privacy-enabled layer-1 blockchain, providing data privacy for Web3 applications in order to solve for usability and security. Smart contracts deployed on Secret Network become "secret contracts," which utilize encrypted inputs, outputs, and state.

The ETH derivatives space as a whole is understandably still very early, but should play a much larger role in the wake of the the Beacon Chain and proof of stake on Ethereum 2.0.

In addition to being available for use across DeFi protocols, DETH could be packaged into a host of other products:

+ ETF-like index products¬†
+ Swap products that allow stakers to fix their yield and traders to speculate on yield¬†
+ Structured products like fixed income
With a large addressable market and multiple flavors of DETH, there will be many additional financial services built on top of ETH staking derivatives.

This flavor of DETH will resemble securitized products like mortgage-backed securities. Where mortgage-backed securities represent the value of an aggregation of many loans, staking derivatives will pool staking positions into a single package and then tokenize them. https://t.co/rBhIz8zmc6

Decentralized staking solutions will also create a flavor of DETH that will depend not on the competency of a single provider, but on the competency of a pool of providers, diversifying the overall slashing risk.
Meanwhile validators will gain the ability to scale their operations without needing to purchase 32 ETH for each validator they run.

Decentralized solutions will reduce the 32 ETH barrier to entry for stakers while allowing them to outsource the infrastructure requirements, giving them liquidity on their stake, all while supporting the decentralization of Ethereum.
These protocols will first allow users to pool their ETH together, then allocate that pooled ETH to a network of validators for staking.

However, staking concentration among centralized providers could threaten Ethereum‚Äôs PoS security. Thankfully, decentralized solutions like @Rocket_Pool and @StaFi_Protocol  will create two sided marketplaces for staking that will match stakers with validators.
Since exchanges are already in the game of capital aggregation and in the past have raced to offer ancillary services outside of trading, there‚Äôs little doubt they will jump at this opportunity.
Exchanges are particularly well positioned to be major DETH issuers, as they‚Äôre among the largest holders of ETH and issuers of other wrapped assets (mainly stablecoins).
Certain ETH derivative tokens may find themselves as illiquid as the underlying ETH locked in the deposit contract so stakers must choose wisely.

Lastly, secondary market liquidity for different flavors of DETH will come into play. Just as the market has settled on a small handful of fiat-backed stablecoins, it will likely settle on a handful of DETH solutions.

Stakers will have to trust that whichever service they stake to is adequately maintaining their validator. Failure to do so will lead to reduced rewards and slashing penalties. Custodial risks will need to be considered as well.
While this will allow stakers to have their cake and eat it too by earning validator rewards while still maintaining liquidity on their ETH, there are considerations to be made.

In addition to managing validator software, these services will accept ETH staking deposits and mint a corresponding amount of DETH for the depositor. DETH will represent a claim on the underlying stake that the depositor can put to work across various DeFi protocols.
We‚Äôre likely to see multiple flavors of DETH issued by exchanges and staking pools that will allow stakers to rehypothecate their staked ETH for use across DeFi.

Before we break down DETH, you can get all of this and more in our full Ethereum 2.0 report.

More broadly, a variety of firms and protocols are beginning to rollout offerings that allow users to securitize their staked ETH for liquidity, giving birth to an entirely new category of derivative ETH, or ‚ÄúDETH.‚Äù

Recognizing the illiquidity and opportunity costs stakers face, multiple solutions have emerged that will allow stakers to gain liquidity on their staked ETH. 

For example, @liquidstake will allow stakers to borrow USDC against ETH staked through their platform.

Validators can earn anywhere from 4-23% yield on their staked ETH, but it‚Äôs difficult to say whether or not that capital could be put to more productive use elsewhere; particularly if the current market momentum continues.
While this indefinite lockup was a security conscious decision made by developers, it imposes a high opportunity cost on stakers.

As for which approach will prevail, only time will tell. But if rollups pan out, Ethereum should be able to maintain its virtual monopoly on DeFi applications while ETH 2.0 remains in its incubation stage.

There‚Äôs still ample opportunity outside of Ethereum, and new Layer-1s can stand out by targeting niche sectors (like Flow and gaming) and bringing radically different designs to the table (like the unparalleled flexibility afforded on Polkadot and Cosmos).
While Ethereum competitors will offer similar technical advantages, Ethereum‚Äôs strong community will continue to serve as its biggest moat.
It is likely that big name DeFi apps won‚Äôt stray too far from Ethereum and will end up on some version of a rollup, if they move from the base layer at all.
It could also negate the need for the final phase of Ethereum 2.0, allowing Ethereum to reach its desired scalability by the end of 2022.
Combined with PoS and sharding, roll-ups would allow Ethereum to support a theoretical max of ~100,000 transactions per second, or a ~10,000x improvement over the current network capacity.
DeFi darling @synthetix_io has already deployed the first application on Optimism‚Äôs public testnet, and some suspect @UniswapProtocol will follow suit.

These include: 

+ @optimismPBC's Optimistic Ethereum 
+ @the_matter_labs‚Äô zkSync  
+ @OffchainLabs‚Äô Arbitrum
While rollups are still a few months away from being production-ready, there‚Äôs already a burgeoning ecosystem forming around various rollup flavors.

Rollups have quickly become the go-to scaling solution for Ethereum‚Äôs PoW chain due to their ability to run smart contracts off-chain. Rollups are essentially new blockchains that process transactions independently of Ethereum before settling batch transactions to the main chain https://t.co/qjLAApJygh
Layer-2 solutions can significantly improve the number of transactions a Layer-1 can process without bogging down the underlying network with excess data and computing requests.
In general, layer-2 scaling solutions facilitate transactions through off-chain means before bundling and submitting them as a single transaction to the base layer.

In the near term, however, Layer-1‚Äôs aren‚Äôt competing with Ethereum 2.0. They‚Äôre in a much tighter race against viable Layer-2 solutions on Ethereum‚Äôs existing PoW chain. In particular, a solution known as ‚Äúrollups‚Äù.

Others are building chains compatible with Ethereum‚Äôs virtual machine (EVM) that will offer familiar environments for Ethereum developers with minimal switching costs:

+ @avalancheavax's Athereum¬†
+ @Polkadot‚Äôs Moonbeam

Several networks are nearing completion on bridges to Ethereum that will allow value on Ethereum to interoperate with applications on competing chains:¬†

+ @NEARProtocol's Rainbow Bridge
+ @cosmos' Peggy
+ @solana's Wormhole
It‚Äôs easy to write off these new networks, as they are miles behind Ethereum in terms of developer firepower, financial middleware, and tradable tokens. But the competition is just getting started.
Those snake-bitten by rising fees will inevitably explore alternative platforms with better transaction throughput and lower fees if they haven‚Äôt already.

Most new Layer-1s, whether it be @cosmos, @Polkadot, or @solana, have built their platforms partially based on the premise that developers and new retail users will grow tired of Ethereum‚Äôs unrelentingly high costs. Their strategy is not wrong.

Meanwhile, nearly every high profile Ethereum competitor has launched or will launch by the end of 2020. The gap between now and a user ready stage of ETH 2.0 leaves an opportunity for other low-fee, low-latency competitors to eat into Ethereum‚Äôs monopoly

This puts Ethereum in a precarious position following this summer‚Äôs DeFi bull market where network congestion created an unpredictable and oftentimes unforgiving fee market for users and developers.
With basic transaction functionality 1-2 years away, ETH 2.0 can‚Äôt be a near term scaling solution for the current network.

The launch of the Beacon Chain only signals the beginning of a multi-year journey towards scalability. Phase 0 is for staking and little else and at present, the Beacon Chain‚Äôs functionality¬†is practically non-existent.

Why do validators stake 32 ETH? 

This number was a deliberate design choice since acquiring this amount is relatively attainable (~$19,000 at current prices) but expensive enough to prevent the validator count from ballooning to a point that would cause network overhead issues.

More on what the introduction of PoS means for $ETH in the full report

.@ConsenSys estimates that in order to match the current security of Ethereum‚Äôs PoW chain, just under 16 million ETH would need to be staked. At this point, validators would be earning a theoretical max of 4.4% per year (all of these figures assume 100% uptime).

How much do validators make? 

The amount of yield that individual validators receive will be based on the total amount of ETH staked. Basically, the rewards validators receive will go down as staking participation goes up. https://t.co/B8BeweIlLc

The main catch here is that the deposit contract is a one-way street. Once ETH is staked, that stake, along with the accrued rewards will be completely immobile until a later phase not anticipated until some time in 2022 (there are proposals that may move this timeline up)

When an aspiring staker makes a valid deposit of 32 ETH or greater, the Beacon Chain mints an equivalent amount of ETH on the new chain. Validators then start accruing ETH rewards in exchange for their services.

What is the deposit contract? 

It's a one-way bridge between Ethereum‚Äôs PoW chain and the Beacon Chain. Currently, there has been over 878,000 ETH (over $530M) staked from over 2,700 unique depositors who have opted to help bootstrap Ethereum‚Äôs proof of stake blockchain.

1) a validator‚Äôs ability to remain online and active  
 
2) the amount of ETH that‚Äôs locked in a special contract called the deposit contract.

In the meantime, Ethereum applications will continue to run uninterrupted on the original PoW chain.

Despite its limited functionality, the Beacon Chain comes with very real economic implications, as new ETH will be issued to PoS validators based on two variables.

Eventually, the Beacon Chain will serve as the central nervous system for the entire Ethereum network. However, upon launch the Beacon Chain‚Äôs primary purpose will just be to bootstrap the new PoS consensus mechanism.
If they perform inadequately or maliciously, they receive reduced rewards and could even risk losing some or all of their stake via a slashing penalty.
If a validator performs adequately, mainly by remaining online and participating honestly in consensus, they are rewarded with newly issued ETH and eventually, transaction fees.

Where proof of work miners help secure a network by running energy intensive, specialized hardware (ASICs), validators make an economic commitment in the form of 32 ETH and run software that validates new transactions.

The Beacon Chain is Ethereum's new blockchain. 

Where Ethereum‚Äôs existing blockchain employs proof of work (PoW) consensus backed by a network of miners, the Beacon Chain employs proof of stake (PoS) consensus backed by a network of validators.
Ethereum 2.0 boils down to launching a new blockchain from scratch with a completely new consensus mechanism and architecture, all without disrupting Ethereum‚Äôs existing $100B+ cryptoeconomy.

This means that if current layer-one protocols embrace rollups, ETH 2.0 as it‚Äôs currently laid out may never fully launch, but Ethereum will reach its desired scalability within the next two years.
Rollups + ‚ÄúPhase 1.5‚Äù would amount to a ~10,000x+ improvement in network processing capacity over the current state of Ethereum.
Rollups are a type of layer 2 scaling technology that process transactions independently of the Ethereum blockchain, but settle snapshots of their state to the main chain.
However, this phase may end up being unnecessary with phases 0-1.5 and the adoption of a layer-2 scaling technique called ‚Äúrollups.‚Äù

Phase 2 (that may never happen)

The final phase of Ethereum 2.0, involves unlocking smart contract execution across some or all the Beacon Chain‚Äôs 64 shards. Additionally, Phase 2 may introduce a new virtual machine.
However, this will not take place until some time in 2022, so the earliest point in which the average Ethereum user today interacts with Ethereum 2.0 is at least one year away.

This will be accomplished by merging all of the smart contracts and transaction data from the PoW chain into a shard under the Beacon chain. At this point, Ethereum will have successfully transitioned from Proof of Work to Proof of Stake.

Phase 1.5 - "The merge" 

Once Ethereum‚Äôs Beacon Chain has a full set of PoS validators securing the network, and the chain has been subdivided into 64 parallel shards, then it will be time to merge Ethereum as we know it today into Ethereum 2.0.
Even when sharding is implemented (possibly around this time next year), the entire Ethereum ecosystem will continue to run in parallel on the proof of work chain.

Phase 1

Once Phase 0 has been completed and ETH 2.0‚Äôs validator set is firmly in place, Phase 1 will implement new architecture for how the Beacon Chain stores data, called sharding. Sharding will subdivide the Beacon Chain into 64 parallel shards.
There will be no applications, transactions, or smart contracts executed on it for some time. That will all continue on Ethereum‚Äôs existing PoW chain for the time being.
When the Beacon Chain launches tomorrow, outside of bootstrapping a network of proof of stake validators, it will have little functionality.

Fixed supply cryptocurrencies like Zcash and Bitcoin aren‚Äôt interesting because their issuance rate halves every four years.

Now that DeFi protocols have proven that they can generate value for token holders, it's time to be more thoughtful about capital allocation. 

The ABCs of DeFi protocol value capture and capture üëá https://t.co/5u6vuHWNcd

There are plenty of ways protocols can use their retained earnings to incentivize growth and reward stakeholders for creating value. 

This could be anything from: 

+ paying developers 
+ incentivizing liquidity providers 
+ rewarding protocol governors 
+ subsidizing users
More generally, protocols may be better off just letting whatever income they do generate accumulate in a treasury, then being more proactive about how to allocate it.

@placeholdervc's @jmonegro touched on this idea recently, where he suggested that protocols should buy back and reissue tokens to incentivize growth rather than buying back and burning tokens in order to return value to shareholders.

So why should DeFi protocols act any differently? 

Instead of buying back tokens, only to burn or distribute those tokens to token holders, and distributing fee income to token holders, DeFi protocols could take a more thoughtful approach to capital allocation.

This is especially true for startups in high growth industries where the potential returns on capital can be enormous if a firm succeeds in its market.

Investors in early stage startups don‚Äôt want dividends and stock buybacks. They want growth and future profits.

Early stage firms rarely use their financial resources to buyback stock or issue dividends to shareholders. 

The reason: 

Why reward shareholders at an early stage when that capital can earn far higher returns when reinvested in the business?

To date, DeFi protocols have only explored 2 of the 5 options for capital allocation:

+ issuing dividends 
+ repurchasing stock (tokens) 

Yet, both of these options are inappropriate for DeFi protocols given their stage of maturity. üßµ

Learn all about the first iteration of fixed-rate loans in crypto in the latest from @jpurd17 https://t.co/bNM9aObGUB
B) Deprives the cryptoeconomy of the ever-so-useful yield curve that can be used to gain valuable insight into market sentiment

To sum it up, the lack of fixed income products in crypto:

A) leaves prospective borrowers with crippling uncertainty. 

For example, $Dai rates started the year at 0.5% and were at 20% a few months later.
Inverted yield curves are a powerful economic indicator that have predicted the last several US recessions. https://t.co/J5YJih9JzI

When the yield curve inverts, meaning long-term rates drop below short-term rates, it means investors are expecting a severe downturn that will lead central banks to lower rates further. 

This leads them to lock in whatever rate they can get.

Why? 

It means lenders require a higher yield to lend over longer time horizons because they deem there to be more profitable opportunities elsewhere. https://t.co/eqae7gASxz

From viewing the yield curve for fixed-rate loans in traditional markets, we're able to gain valuable insight into investor sentiment.

For example, a steeper yield curve implies investors believe there are good times ahead.

Fixed income loans allow investors to earn a predetermined interest rate over a set time period

They also give borrowers certainty around the interest rate they will need to pay on their loans 

Crypto lenders and borrowers are currently at the mercy of volatile interest rates

A primer on yield curves and why they matter for crypto.

First: what's a yield curve? 

The yield curve traditionally measures the yield of fixed-income loans across different maturity dates. https://t.co/bJ9eIqvmMH

Fixed-rate yields have been absent from crypto, leaving DeFi lenders at the mercy of volatile interest rates

+ @yieldprotocol's fixed-term Dai loans

But how can DeFi protocols most effectively monetize these balance sheets? 

We explore that question in depth in our latest üëáhttps://t.co/WOwkcVNPHQ

DeFi protocols are similar, except without the trusted third party in the middle directing the activity. 

DeFi protocols are just coordinators that facilitate activity between peers, where disputes are enforced using smart contracts on public blockchains. https://t.co/JzvOx4zX61

How much value a protocol creates for its stakeholders depends on how effectively a protocol can monetize its balance sheet. 

Balance sheet monetization as a business model is not new. It‚Äôs how banks have generated cash flow for millenia 

Take deposits --> monetize via lending

Users provide their capital to protocols in exchange for value flows. 

These flows can either be intrinsic to the system, such as liquidity-mined governance tokens, or extrinsic to the system, such as fees paid in stablecoins and other cryptoassets.

DeFi protocols are coordination mechanisms that define rules and provide incentives in order to facilitate financial activity. 

Most DeFi protocols do this by crowdsourcing assets from their communities and putting those assets to productive use.

At the core of the DeFi business model is a protocol‚Äôs balance sheet.

DeFi protocols create value by monetizing a community balance sheet (TVL) https://t.co/q3OF82hHwc

PoolTogether presents an opportunity to change the negative consequences associated with traditional lotteries. 

Since losing tickets are refunded, nobody loses their hard-earned money. 

This has the ability to benefit millions of individuals that addictively play the lottery.

PoolTogether takes the $Dai from ticket sales and allocates the funds to a lending protocol like @compoundfinance, where it earns interest. 

Each week, the winner of the lottery receives the combined interest and everyone else has their initial funds returned.

Anyone can purchase a ticket for 1 $Dai and at the end of the week, a winner is selected.

Instead of receiving funds from everyone who purchased losing tickets - as with your traditional state run lottery - PoolTogether takes an innovative approach.

PoolTogether has paid out nearly $30,000 in winnings to various individuals since its launch in 2019.

UMA‚Äôs Data Verification Mechanism:

The team believes blockchain oracles are vulnerable to attacks, which means every smart contract that relies on off-chain data is susceptible to corruption. 

UMA designed an ‚Äúhonest‚Äù oracle with economic incentives to discourage bad behavior. https://t.co/2Eosl8Frue

Trustless tokenization:

Synthetic tokens are created by fully collateralizing one side of an UMA contract and then minting tokens backed by that collateral. 

This allows for the creation of ERC-20 tokens that represent synthetic exposure to the contract‚Äôs reference asset https://t.co/PCNFCY8TTB

UMA uses "priceless financial contracts" that can function without the need of on-chain price feeds, and attempt to avoid exposure to oracle attacks by minimizing their use as part of the protocol https://t.co/K1arn2jLi4
The UMA architecture establishes a framework for creating synthetic assets on Ethereum. https://t.co/KiZvsGFAaQ

Launch style: IEO

UMA initially created 100,000,000 tokens. Approximately, 48,500,000 are held by the Risk Labs founders, early contributors, and seed investors all subject to a multi-year vesting period. https://t.co/mZHo1H2HDL

$UMA Token type: ERC-20

Usage: Voting https://t.co/0gWdgxcphY

UMA was founded by @allilulllc and @hal2001 with the goal to enable users to transfer risk across the internet without the need of central authorities

Advisors include @cburniske, @jillruthcarlson and @njess https://t.co/PRoIngO4QD

Our @UMAprotocol profile has been updated, thanks to community analyst @RobertoTalamas (give him a follow!)

When it comes to these new AMM ‚ÄúIDO‚Äù offerings, if you can submit orders within seconds of the offering going live while bidding up gas prices to get your transaction added first, then there‚Äôs profit to be made.

The only tokens sit in an AMM pool, which by default, can only be bought. 

This means that the fastest bots are competing over a risk free trade because initially, the price cannot possibly go down.

These IDOs (Initial Dex Offering) conducted on AMMs like Uniswap are designed with a "fair distribution" in mind. 

In practice, these IDOs often turn into a competitive game amongst the most advanced bots to front-run the retail market.

In the latest incarnation of the ICO, several early participants typically make off with outsized returns while others are left deeply in the red.

@krakenfx and @binance have already listed and redenominated DOTs as New DOT. 

However, not all exchanges have completed the process, so pay attention to the price and the ticker used. See this Polkadot blog post for more information. https://t.co/Nfv48N50ky

This event will not affect the total valuation of the network or any user's account.

The total supply of DOTs and any account balances will be 100x higher. But the price per DOT will be 100x lower than the original auction sale.

On approximately Aug. 21, 2020, $DOT tokens will undergo a redenomination from its original auction sale. 

This redenomination will split the DOTs 100:1, meaning New DOT will be 100x smaller than DOT (old).

Bitcoin is a fixed supply asset. 

Where increased demand for gold will lead miners to dig up more of it, an increase in the demand for bitcoin cannot increase its supply. 

The only way to increase the price of an inelastic good like bitcoin is to increase demand. https://t.co/zM2iIMDDif

‚ÄúWhile the S2F model is often masqueraded around by halving bulls to prove the price of bitcoin will rise after the halving, a simple lesson from your intro to microeconomics class does wonders to swiftly rebut this notion." - @jpurd17

When the halving arrives, #Bitcoin's flow will be cut in half, strengthening this narrative 

Historically, S2F has held up, as the price of $BTC has risen after each of the last 2 halvings

Correlation does not however suggest causation https://t.co/nbeJSKGbVO https://t.co/OMI8YAWHGx

Stock = total outstanding inventory (~17M)

Flow = amount of mined each year 

BTC S2F = 53 years (it would take 53 years for BTC mined annual to equal outstanding supply) https://t.co/TTopcS8AXH

The largest real estate ETF, $VNQ, quintupled over the last decade

This surge is greater than that of the S&P500's, in part due to the enormous amount of leverage used in commercial REITs

Adding insult to injury, commercial real estate will be hit hardest by #COVID

Bubble #3: The commercial real estate bubble 

In 2008, we had a residential real estate crisis. This time, it‚Äôs their commercial counterpart. 

Total commercial real estate loans at U.S. banks have surged by over 50% ($700B) since 2012 https://t.co/Ibvh6vSm6i

If you overlay China's corporate debt, the US's pales in comparison 

Borrowing money to fuel growth is the core of capitalism 

There is a tipping point however, when companies have too much debt to service and not enough cash to weather a downturn. Like right now. https://t.co/NiwnfNwWhx

Bubble #3: Corporate debt bubble 

The US currently has the largest corporate debt burden in US history, overtaking the prior record of 72% set in 2008 https://t.co/6L2ru97zmc

Buybacks fueled by: 

+ Trump's corporate tax cuts 
+ historically low interest rates
+ few investment opportunities
+ misaligned executive incentives

Executives used tax cuts & cheap capital to pump their shares and boost their bonuses 

Now the largest market bidders are gone

Bubble #2: The buyback bubble

From 2009 to 2019, companies in the S&P500 bought $5.3 trillion of their own shares. 

FIVE TRILLION https://t.co/8UlRXjncST

A cult of passive investing was fueled by: 

+ ability to easily park money in 500 stocks at once
+ public encouragement from investors like @WarrenBuffett 
+ the longest bull market in history 

Momentum outperformed value; a vicious circle

Shortly after this piece was published, $BTC spiked on news that the Fed was cutting rates 50bps 

This marks the first time BTC has immediately reacted to such an event, which could further signal that its arrival as an emerging macro asset is already here https://t.co/tNrFODViyC

Bitcoin was too small to respond to past monetary events like QE3 in 2012

At $160 billion, it may still be too small to offer investors protection, but perhaps not.

Upcoming monetary actions could be larger and institutional infrastructure for $BTC is now in place

#Bitcoin is not a hedge against economic recessions

It is a hedge against fiat currency and the mismanagement of fiat monetary systems

The better dynamic to track is how $BTC responds to central bank stimulus in the near term https://t.co/cd9qZIvyZT

$BTC was not immune to the action, falling more than 10% alongside risk-on assets and even gold

Amidst the downturn, US treasury bonds rallied hard, with yields plummeting to their lowest point in history

Helium 2020: 

2019 was focused entirely on getting hotspots out there. 2020 will be all about demand-side usage. 

They have a big pipeline of potential users and an exciting announcement related to their work with the developer community coming soon. 

Thanks @amirhaleem!

How enterprises view building on decentralized networks:

They actually aren‚Äôt turned off by the fact it‚Äôs built on a crypto network since that part is abstracted away. To them it looks like AWS credits. 

"They are more in disbelief that the network actually exists and works!"

Why a blockchain:

It comes down to trust.

Lastly, mining is a different business in 2020 than in the past 

+ Miners are much better capitalized and less reliant on selling $BTC to pay operating costs 

+ Derivatives markets have matured, allowing miners to hedge price risk and operate profitably amidst price declines

‚õèÔ∏èPotential miner selling pressure heading into 2020 is nearly identical to that of 2016 

(probably less so as our data does not reflect volumes from OTC trading and certain exchanges)

This was NOT the case during the second halving in 2016

üîáTrading volumes had increased 10x and total potential miner sell pressure encompassed a mere 3.4% of total volume

This was the case in 2012's first halving since miner selling encompassed a significant % of total volumes 

üìâ Potential sell pressure decreased from 135% to 67% https://t.co/lZSDXFL4ms

Debunking S2F: 

Pointing to the historical correlation between Bitcoin‚Äôs price and its S2F is not enough

Correlation does not imply causation, unless you are also willing to concede that Bitcoin prices respond to Mexican Avocado prices. https://t.co/CZ9Ew69kTp

Bull Thesis 2: S2F (Stock to Flow)

Theory posits that $BTC will rise as a function of supply dynamics 

May's halving will introduce scarcity that will send BTC to $55K as popularized by @100trillionUSD's model https://t.co/M5qgLbzuI3

Debunking EMH: 

EMH only requires enough rational participants to be aware of the halving for markets to be efficient. 

Since most entities trading $BTC are aware of the halving, markets are likely efficient

Bull Thesis 1: EMH 

$BTC markets are not efficient because certain participants are not aware of the halving and its impact on price

Once these uniformed participants learn of the halving, they will flood market, raising the price

üßµWhy @jpurd17 and @RyanWatkins_ think popular bitcoin halving theories have little fundamental basis

2 bull theories:  

1. The Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH) 

2. Stock to flow https://t.co/Ieggn4vGDa

Theoretically, all else equal, a higher Stock to Flow lead to less selling pressure on the supply side, potentially more people willing to hold the asset on the demand side, and ultimately higher price.

(The keyword here is "all else equal".)
While there are a lot of debates in the community around the details of the statistical model, the essence of the research is sound:

As such, the lower the expected increase in Liquid Supply, through mechanisms like mining, staking, and founders' reward, the higher Stock to Flow ratio, and the higher the scarcity.

For instance, BTC's current Stock to Flow is about 30, and will double upon the next halving.

Stock To Flow is a measure of scarcity popularized in the crypto community by @saifedean and more recently by @100trillionUSD.

Per our methodology, Stock is defined by the current Liquid Supply. Flow is defined by the expected increase in Liquid Supply over the next 12 months.

Check out the Stock To Flow ratio for 90+ assets on our screener!

https://t.co/dGeetPXawZ https://t.co/azQ38tzR9r

@rcrsv There's no simple answer to that. There might be a positive feedback loop between transaction and value. The regression by itself doesn't imply any direct causal relationship between the variables.
Feel free to check out the underlying data here: https://t.co/sukCXDw8zR

This may remind you of Metcalfe's Law, which predicts that the value of a network is proportional to the *square* of nodes.

However, our regression suggests that the relationship, in our context, is closer to being linear.
Here's the line of best fit between the number of transactions and liquid market cap. https://t.co/9Z9gU3ZZKa
Here's the line of best fit between active addresses and liquid market cap. https://t.co/4y4Y58b1eE

It turns out that, unsurprisingly, there is a strong positive relationship between market cap and on-chain activities.

Below is the line of best fit between transaction volume and liquid market cap. Each dot is a cryptoasset. https://t.co/0UQ35ddOZY

First, some background on cross-sectional studies.

A cross-section, in the context of crypto, is a snapshot of multiple assets at one point in time.

This contrasts with time series, where one looks at how one asset evolves over time.

It's well known that, in the long run, the market cap of Bitcoin grows in tandem with on-chain activities.

But what about other cryptoassets? Is there any relationship between market cap and on-chain metrics?

Today we did a cross-sectional study.

Miners prefer ASICs because of their power and efficiency. But how do they work?

Find the answers here

Large caps tend to be more stable than small caps.

You can learn more about our price, volume, and supply methodology here: https://t.co/Obb0lheZY0

We always welcome feedback on our efforts to move the industry forward!

While we believe our methodology is sound, we don't necessarily think other sites are wrong‚Äîthis calculation isn‚Äôt black and white. But the industry should reach consensus on this because reporting different prices can be confusing to newcomers.

Our aggregate price for a given asset only includes pairs whose base is the given asset. For instance, our BTC price includes BTC/USD pairs, but not implied BTC prices of ETH/BTC pairs.

This is because the quote asset is generally more liquid than the base asset.

The exchanges we do include are the "Real 10" exchanges, which we believe with high conviction have 100% real volume.

These exchanges tend to list BTC/USD pairs, rather than BTC/USDT pairs.

We have excluded Bitfinex from our aggregate price calculation even before the Tether news. This is because Bitfinex charged significant withdrawal fees, which caused the price on Bitfinex to trade at a significant premium.

Since the Tether news broke, the price of Bitcoin reported on https://t.co/HZGfNqqiPI has been quite different from some other data sites. Sometimes by as much as 2 percent.

Because our model relies on a variety of assumptions (e.g. cost and  revenue following the same trend, no impact on price from Binance releasing vested tokens, etc.), we welcome critiques and suggestions for improvement. /end

We estimate future coinburns to include 600,000 $BNB, and we apply a similar relative deflation to each supply tranche (Binance, Angel Investors & ICO Participants) until 2050. BNB‚Äôs supply model is challenging, maybe one of the trickiest projects we‚Äôve studied to date. (...)

But other developments (e.g. fees discount rate reduction, fiat on-ramp service) could indicate a future increase in trading volume, neutralizing the effect of a price increase on future nominal $BNB coinburns. (...)
In the mid-term, a few structural reasons (e.g. Binance Launchpad and Binance DEX) support the idea that $BNB will keep its relative value and market cap ranking. (...)

In Q1 2019, $BNB price increased significantly while trading volumes decreased, with daily average $USD volume 4-5x lower than Q1 2018. Our assumption is that we will see much lower coinburns (in nominal $BNB) in the near future due to a decreasing USD/BNB trading volume. (...)

This is Binance Coin's supply curve. View the full $BNB asset profile here: https://t.co/RicspdtDPg 

These are our model's core assumptions: https://t.co/vgju4j3aZW

@Michael14140889 One thing I would like to ask is, can you provide a link to any Messari employee discussing XRP the way that you mentioned? To the best of our knowledge, no one from our team has discussed XRP in any such way. 

If there is anything I missed respond or email me at eric@messari.io

@Michael14140889 There is a lot of nuance, and we will use our supply framework to address all assets where we have the capacity. We are bringing on additional team members to do exactly this. As mentioned before, you will see more insights very soon.

@Michael14140889 When we are able to find reported paper contracts that restrict tokens we will likely exclude those from supply. In cases where we can make well-reasoned estimates, we will do so. 

What we want to fully understand is CAN someone reasonably add tokens to existing supply.

@Michael14140889 Things like "lost coins" or smart contracts that are controlled by an individual are likely outside of this scope for a variety of reasons. We do indeed hope that teams work with us to disclose true supply, but are continuing to build out an infrastructure that can track this.

@Michael14140889 To address some of the points you brought up we feel comfortable excluding tokens from circulating supply if they are locked up by legal agreements, vesting schedules that are coded into smart contracts, and other verifiable reasons to assume tokens are not circulating.

@Michael14140889 This was one of what will likely be many reports on how supply, and by relation market cap, could be better measured for projects. It was in no way meant to be anti-XRP and as tokens are released into circulating supply we will update our numbers.

@Michael14140889 We have been working our way down the list of the top 50 assets by market cap. Being that XRP was top three it was something we discovered during our research. If you visit our site we have created supply curves for many of the top assets

@Michael14140889 Hey, @Michael14140889 I just saw this and apologize if the original post was lost in our mentions before. We have publicly posted our methodology for supply here: https://t.co/lARgJvB2Ze

We have been thinking about how to make these metrics better for a long time. We will be releasing a framework outlining types of supply for public feedback and hope the industry can agree on common standards.

In some cases it is easy to identify these restrictions, and adjust circulating supply over time. In others, it is more difficult. But better supply measures are important for a range of network statistics, not just market cap, which is clearly a confusing measure in crypto.

This is one area that we disagree with @ForbesCrypto on when it comes to supply. If coins can‚Äôt be used do they have any value? Legal, smart contract, and other restrictions that make it impossible to transfer coins should reduce circulating supply. https://t.co/JE9SiPOwBg

If they are lost forever there is a good argument they should be excluded from circulating supply. Along with other clearly lost coins. We have been waiting for more details on the situation. For example: https://t.co/RnwI3sHZZZ

At which point should the @QuadrigaCoinEx coins are considered lost forever?

If you think it‚Äôs a different time let us know in the replies.
